en: Deputy Education Minister-designate and Member of Parliament for Assin South Rev. John Ntim Fordjour has assured teachers their welfare concerns are a priority to government.

en: According to him, plans are underway to launch a Teacher Welfare App to promptly address teachers’ welfare grievances.

en: Speaking to the media at the 90th-anniversary celebration of the Ghana National Association of Teachers (GNAT) in Accra where he represented the sector minister, John Ntim Fordjour charged the teacher unions to have confidence in the ability of government to find solutions to the current challenges in the sector.
twi: John Ntim Fordɛour de too akyerɛkyerɛfoɔ kuo ahodoɔ no anim sɛ, wɔnnya gyidie wɔ aban no mu sɛ aban no bɛsi wɔn haw ano. ɔde saa nsɛm yi too dwa berɛ na ɔne nsɛntwerɛfoɔ redi nkitaho wɔ Ghana National Association of Teachers (GNAT) afofida a ɛtɔ so aduakron.
mt0: <pad> Ghana National Association of Teachers (GNAT) 90th-anniversary celebrations in Accra where he represented the sector minister, John Ntim Fordjour charged the teacher unions to have confidence in the ability of government to find solutions to the current challenges in the sector.</s>

en: The occasion which was also used as an investment forum was on the theme: “Beyond Teachers’ Fund; Making the Teacher Economically Sound.”
twi: Wɔde saa ahyiamudie yi nso kyerɛkyerɛ wɔn adwene faa sikasie ho a na ti asɛm no yɛ “Beyond Teachers’ Fund; Making the Teacher Eɔonomiɔally Sound”.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkwan no a wɔde di dwuma ne sɛ ɔmanfo yɛ adwuma ho forum no kɔɔ so wɔ ɔkwan a ɛwɔ ɔkwan: “Beyond Teachers’ Fund; Making the Teacher Economically Sound.”</s>

en: Addressing the leadership and members of GNAT, he intimated that teachers across the country have contributed immensely to the socio-economic development of the nation. He reiterated government’s commitment to timeously address teacher welfare concerns.
twi: ɔde too GNAT mpaninfoɔ ne kuomma no anim sɛ, akyerɛkyerɛfoɔ a wɔwɔ ɔman no mu aboa ama ɔman no atu mpɔn. ɔsan nso sii so dua sɛ, aban no bɛsɔ haw ahodoɔ a akyerɛkyerɛfoɔ refa mu no ano.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ɔbɛkyerɛ GNAT leadership ne nnipa a wɔwɔ hɔ no sɛ, 'Teachers have contributed immensely to the socio-economic development of the nation.</s>

en: He expressed delight at the judicious and productive initiatives undertaken by GNAT in their bid to improve the lots of its members. He particularly commended the business exploits of GNAT including the acquisition of majority shares in Unique Insurance and the Sweden Ghana Medical Centre. He also commended the GNAT for its investments in real estate and the rolling out of a housing scheme for members.
twi: ɔbɔɔ GNAT abɔ sɛ wɔde nhyehyɛeɛ ahodoɔ agu akwan sɛ wɔbɛma wɔn ase atrɛ. ɔbɔɔ GNAT aba so wɔ wɔn dwadie ho nhyehyɛeɛ sɛ wɔbɛnya kyɛfa kɛseɛ wɔ Unique Insurance ne Sweden Ghana Medical Centre mu. ɔsan nso bɔɔ GNAT aba so sɛ wɔde wɔn ho ahyɛ adansie adwuma no mu and wɔresisi adan ama wɔn kuomma no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔde ne ho too gua wɔ GNAT's adeɛ a ɛyɛ adwuma mu ne nsɛm a ɛkɔ so wɔ ɔkwan a wɔde bɛkyerɛ nnipa a wɔwɔ no.</s>

en: Rev. Ntim Fordjour assured teachers that the Ministry of Education will in due course make available 280,000 laptops to teachers on cost-sharing basis to equip them deliver more effectively.
twi: Rev. Ntim Fordjour hyɛɛ akyerɛkyerɛfoɔ bɔ sɛ nkyɛn biara asoeɛ a ɛhwɛ nwomasua so bɛma akyerɛkyerɛfoɔ kɔmputa 280,000 a wɔbɛfa ɛka no mu fa sɛdeɛ ɛbɛyɛ a wɔbɛtumi ayɛ wɔn adwuma yie.
mt0: <pad> Rev. Ntim Fordjour assured teachers that the Ministry of Education will in due course make available 280,000 laptops to teachers on cost-sharing basis to equip them deliver more effectively.</s>

en: He called on all teachers across the length and breath of the country to join hands with the Ministry of Education to build a world-class education system.

en: Four people have been swept away by floodwater at Bomso in the Oforikrom Municipality of the Ashanti region after a heavy downpour on Thursday 24th June 2021.
twi: Nsuo afa nnipa baanan wɔ Bomso a ɛwɔ Oforikrom nkuroakɛseɛ mu a ɛwɔ Asante Mantam mu aberɛ nsu kɛseɛ tɔeɛ Yawoada, Kɔtɔnima da a ɛtɔ so aduonu nan mu.
mt0: <pad> Four people have been swept away by floodwater at Bomso in the Oforikrom Municipality of the Ashanti region after a heavy downpour on Thursday 24th June 2021.</s>

en: The assembly member for the Bomso electoral area Isaac Appiah who confirmed the unfortunate development said, a search team will be deployed on Friday to find the missing people.
twi: Asɛmbele mɛmba (assembly member) a ɛwɔ Bomso abatoɔ mansini mu, Isaaɔ Appiah a ɔde too dwa sɛ ampa ara asɛm yi asi kyerɛ sɛ, wato nnipa tɔɔ mmɔtene so Fiada no sɛ wɔnkɔhwehwɛ nnipa a wɔayera no.

en: Kumasi, the capital of Ashanti region has for the past two days witnessed serious flood disasters destroying properties worth millions of Ghana cedis.
twi: Nsu kɛseɛ pa ara na atɔ wɔ Kumasi, a ɛyɛ Asante mantam mu kuropɔn no mu nna mmienu atwa yi a asɛesɛe agyapadeɛ a ɛbɛyɛ sika ɔpepem biara.
mt0: <pad> Kumasi, a ɛyɛ Ashanti Region ahenkuro no, nsutɔ a ɛkɔ so wɔ nna mmienu akyi no ayɛ sɛ ɛbɛma nsuo a ɛho yɛ hu a ɛde Ghana cedis ɔpepem pii na ɛdae.</s>

en: The Kumasi Kejetia Market equally had its share of the flood on Wednesday where several shops in the new market flooded destroying goods.
twi: Kumasi Kejetia dwom nso nyaa ne kyɛfa wɔ nsuo a ɛtɔɔ Wukuada no. Nsuo no yiri faa adan a ɛwɔ dwom na ɛsee nnoɔma bebree.
mt0: <pad> Kumasi Kejetia Market nso nyaa ne ho wɔ nsuyiri no mu Wednesday a ɛbɛyɛɛ sɛ ɛtɔɔ nsuo a ɛde nneɛma bɛkɔɔ a, na ɛhweree adeɛ a ɛwɔ hɔ.</s>

en: The mayor of Kumasi Osei Asibey Antwi who is on sick leave told Starr FM’s Ashanti regional Correspondent Isaac Justice Bediako that the KMA technical team will hold an emergency meeting on the flooding development in Kumasi.
twi: Kumasi meyɔ (mayorɔ, Osei Asibey Antwi ɔregye n’ahome ɛsiane sɛ ɔyare nti, de too Starr FM amannebɔfoɔ a ɔwɔ Asante mantam mu, Isaaɔ Justice Bediako sɛ KMA tɛknekal kuo no bɛhyiam adwennwene nsuoyiri a ɛrekɔ so wɔ Kumasi no ho.
mt0: <pad> Kumasi mayor Osei Asibey Antwi a ɔwɔ yareɛ leave kae Starr FM’s Ashanti regional Correspondent Isaac Justice Bediako sɛ KMA technical team no bɛyɛ emergency meeting wɔ Kumasi nsuo mu nsuo a ɛda nso.</s>

en: “This morning the assembly technical and the planning committee will hold an emergency meeting on the development. Since my life in Kumasi, I have [not] seen the city flooding like this before. Currently, we need to put together a serious comprehensive plan, our gutters are too small to carry the floodwaters,” he said.
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ, “asɛmbele tɛknikal ne nhyehyɛeɛ kɔmitee no bɛhyiam anɔpa yi adwennwene nsuoyiri no ho. Mebɛtenaa Kumasi nyinaa yi, menhunuu nsuoyiri bi sei da. Seisei ara deɛ, ɛwɔ sɛ yɛde nhyehyɛeɛ mapa gu akwan mu, yɛn gata no susua sɛ nsuo bɛfam.”
mt0: <pad> “Nnɛ a assembly technical and the planning committee bɛyɛ emergency meeting wɔ ɔkwan a ɛsɛ sɛ yɛde yɛn adwene bɛka saa adeɛ no ho. Since my life in Kumasi, I have [not] seen the city flooding like this before. Currently, we need to put together a serious comprehensive plan, our gutters are too small to carry the floodwaters,” he said.</s>

en: He added that the committee after the meeting will tour the affected areas to look at how best the assembly can assist the victims and also look at the immediate measures the assembly can put in place.
twi: ɔde kaa ho sɛ, sɛ nhyiamudie no kɔ awieeɛ a, kɔmitee no bɛbɔ nsra wɔn mmeaeɛ a nsuo yiri yi asɛe hɔ no na wahwɛ kwan a asɛmbele no bɛtumi aboa wɔn a wɔn ho aka no, na afei nso wɔahunu nhyehyɛeɛ a asɛmbele no de bɛgu akwan mu.

en: Some residents of the Effia-Kwesimintsim Municipality and the Sekondi Takoradi Metropolis have expressed fears over what they say is the increasing spate of robberies in the area.
twi: Wɔn a wɔte Effia-Kwesimintsim nkuroakɛseɛmu ne Sekondi Takoradi kuropɔn mu kyerɛ ɛhu na abɔ wɔn ɛnam korɔno a ate atese wɔ wɔn atenaeɛ mu.
mt0: <pad> Residents of Effia-Kwesimintsim Municipality and Sekondi Takoradi Metropolis have expressed fears over what they say is the increasing spate of robberies in the area.</s>

en: It follows the mob arrest of two out of three suspected robbers at Tanokrom, a suburb of the Effia-Kwesimintsim Municipality after the suspects on a speeding motorbike snatched a bag containing an undisclosed amount of money from a lady around the ‘God is Love chop bar’ area.
twi: Wɔde wei too dwa berɛ wɔkyɛɛ akorɔmfoɔ mmiɛnsa mu no mmienu wɔ Tanokrom, borɔno bi a ɛhyɛ Effia-Kwesimintsim nkuroakɛseɛ ase. Saa akorɔmfoɔ yi a na wɔte moto so de ammirika hyimm ɔbaa bi baagi a sika a wɔammɔ din hyɛ mu wɔ ‘Nyame yɛ ɔdɔ’ adidibea.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkyeree no kɔɔ so wɔ Tanokrom, a ɛyɛ Effia-Kwesimintsim Municipality suburb bere a suspects no kɔɔ so wɔ motobike na wɔde bag a ɛwɔ undisclosed amount of money afiri nnipa a wɔwɔ ‘God is Love chop bar’ area.</s>

en: Luck, however, eluded them after they were given a hot chase and later apprehended close to the Takoradi Mall but one managed to escape in the process and is currently at large.
twi: Wɔn tiri anyɛ yie aberɛ wɔde guu wɔn so kɔkyɛɛ wɔn Takoradi Mall nkyɛn na mmom baako bɔɔ mmɔden dwaneeɛ a ɔde ne ho aka nwura.
mt0: <pad> Ɛmfa ho, wɔn ahoɔden kɔɔ wɔn akyi bere a wɔde wɔn nanteɛ na wɔkyeree wɔn wɔ Takoradi Mall no mu nanso baako pɛɛ na ɔbɛtumi anya kwan sɛ ɔbɛfiri saa dwumadi no mu na ɔwɔ hɔ ɛnnɛ.</s>

en: Bystanders who witnessed the incident reportedky handed the robbers severe beatings before they were handed over to the police. The victim was lucky to have had been given her valuables.
twi: Wɔn a na wɔatwa hɔ ahyia no bɔɔ akorɔmfoɔ yi kama ansa na wɔde wɔrehyɛ apolisifoɔ nsa. ɔbaa a wɔwiee no no ti yɛɛ yie ɛsiane sɛ ɔnyaa ne baagi no a na biribiara wɔ mu.

mt0: <pad> Last weekend, Anaji SSNIT flats residents had to sacrifice their sleep as a gang of motor riders took over the area to display their riding skills till the morning.</s>

en: Again on Monday morning June 21, three suspects on a motorbike were captured on CCTV camera attempting to break into a popular pub at Anaji Westline Back in the Sekondi-Takoradi Metropolis. The Assemblymember of the Amanful West electoral and Takoradi Constituency Chairman of the ruling New Patriotic Party (NPP) Prince Kojo Arthur has for the umpteenth time complained about how the riders are endangering the lives of people.
twi: Bio, ɔɔTV kamera kyɛɛ nkorɔfoɔ mmiɛnsa bi a na wɔte moto sɛ wɔpɛ sɛ wɔbɔwura beaeɛ a wɔnom nsa wɔn Anaɛi Westline wɔ Sekondi-Takoradi kuropɔn mu. Prince Kojo Arthur a ɛyɛ asɛmbele mɛmba ma Amanful West na ɔsan nso yɛ Takoradi abatoɔ mpasua titenani ma aban a ɔte so, New Patriotic Party kyerɛɛ sɛdeɛ saa motokafoɔ yi reteetee wɔn abrabɔ si fa.
mt0: <pad> CCTV cameras captured three suspects on a motorbike attempting to break into a popular pub at Anaji Westline Back in the Sekondi-Takoradi Metropolis. The Assemblymember of the Amanful West electoral and Takoradi Constituency Chairman of the ruling New Patriotic Party (NPP) Prince Kojo Arthur has for the umpteenth time complained about how the riders are endangering the lives of people.</s>

en: He said several reports to the police about the criminal activities of the motor riders have all not received favorable responses.
twi: ɔkyerɛ sɛ wɔannya mmuaeɛ biara amfiri apolisifoɔ hɔ ɛmfa ho ne amannebɔ ahodoɔ a wɔabɔ afa nnebɔne ahodoɔ a saa motokafoɔ yi reyɛ ho.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaeɛ sɛ wɔde nsɛm pii ayɛ kyerɛɛ ɔmanpanin no sɛ moto riders no yɛ adeɛ a wɔyɛ a, nanso wɔnhunu nsɛm a ɛho hia.</s>

en: Nelson Roland, a robbery victim sharing his ordeal said a motor rider rammed into his back bumper while in traffic and when he decided to step outside the car to check the extent of damage, he returned to realize his iPhone 12 and other valuables on the front seat of his car had been stolen within a spate of two minutes.
twi: Nelson Roland a akorɔmfo afa ne nnoɔma pɛn reka n’akosɛm de too dwa sɛ, motakafoɔ bi de ne moto bɔɔ ne kaa bɔmpa mu wɔ trafeke mu. Na berɛ ɔsi firii ne kaa mu sɛ ɔrekɔhwɛ sɛdeɛ ne kaa no asi asɛe asi afa no, ɔbaeɛ a, na wɔafa ne Iphone 12 ne nnoɔma bi a ɛsom bo a na ɔgu ne kaa no akonnwa mu. Wɔde sima bɛyɛ mmienu na ɛdii saa dwuma no.

en: Some market women and traders at the Koforidua Central market who were customers of defunct Fanteakwa Rural Bank have resurfaced with fresh agitations over their locked-up savings.
twi: Dwadifoɔ a wɔwɔ Koforidua Dwakɛseɛ mu a na wɔsie wɔn sika wɔ Fanteakwa Rural Bank de kwaadu foforɔ abɔ sikakorabea no ɛfa wɔn sika a wɔntumi nyi no ho.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman no mu nnipa ne adetɔnfoɔ a wɔwɔ Koforidua Central Market a na wɔyɛ Fanteakwa Rural Bank adehyeɛfoɔ no rebɛka wɔn ho sɛ wɔn sika a wɔde sii wɔn nsa no ayɛ abotan no.</s>

en: The agitating victims have called on President Akufo-Addo and the Speaker of Parliament, Alban Bagbin as well as the Bank of Ghana to help them retrieve their monies.
twi: Saa adwadifoɔ yi de dwaatowa ato ɔmampanim Akufo-Addo ne mmarahyɛbadwam kyeame, Alban Bagbin ne Bank of Ghana anim sɛ wɔmmoa na wɔn nsa nka wɔn sika.
mt0: <pad> Ghanafoɔ a wɔn ho yɛ hu no de wɔn nsa kaa sɛ wɔbɛboa President Akufo-Addo ne Speaker of the House, Alban Bagbin ne Bank of Ghana sɛ wɔbɛboa wɔn sɛ wɔbɛgye wɔn sika a wɔde sii no.</s>

en: Fanteakwa Rural Bank owned by the incumbent MP for Fanteakwa North Amankwah Asiamah was established in the year 2004 but collapsed in 2012.
twi: Wɔtee Fanteakwa Rural Bank a ɛyɛ Fanteakwa North mmarahyɛbɛdwani, Amankwah Asiamah dea wɔ afe mpem mmienu ne nan mu na mmom ɛguiiɛ wɔ afe mpem mmienu ne du-mmienu mu.
mt0: <pad> Fanteakwa Rural Bank a MP Amankwah Asiamah yɛ no abɛyɛɛ no wɔ 2004 nanso ɛkɔɔ so wɔ 2012</s>

en: The Bank had its headquarters at Begoro and branches in Koforidua, Osiem, Suhum, Anyinam, and other parts of the region.
twi: Saa sikakorabea yi ti wɔ Begoro na ne nkorabata wɔ Koforidua, Osiem, Suhum, Anyinam ne mmeaeɛ ahodoɔ a ɛyɛ mantam no mu.
mt0: <pad> Bank no yɛɛ ne ahenkuro wɔ Begoro na n'akyi wɔ Koforidua, Osiem, Suhum, Anyinam, ne beae afoforɔ a ɛwɔ ɔman no mu.</s>

en: It is estimated that over 1,000 customers had their funds locked up.
twi: Wɔsusu sɛ nnipa bɛyɛ apem na na wɔsie wɔn sika wɔ saa sikakorabea yi.
mt0: <pad> Ɛyɛ sɛ wɔbɛka sɛ nnipa 1,000 na wɔde wɔn sika akɔdɔm no akɔdɔm wɔn nsa.</s>

en: The victims are mostly farmers, traders, drivers, teachers, fetish priests, small-scale miners, and small-scale enterprises.
twi: Wɔn a wɔn sika aka mu no dodoɔ no ara yɛ akuafoɔ, adwadifoɔ, adrɔɔbafoɔ, akyerɛkyerɛfoɔ, asɔfoɔ, wɔn a wɔtu fam agudie ne wɔn a wɔtɔtɔn nnoɔma.
mt0: <pad> Ɔhaw no ne mmoa, nsrahwɛfoɔ, kyerɛkyerɛfoɔ, fetish priests, small-scale miners, and small-scale enterprises.</s>

en: The locked-up funds unleashed hardship on the victims some of whom died as a result while affected small scale enterprises collapsed
twi: Wɔn sika a aka mu no de ahokyerɛ na aba wɔn so ama ebi nso afam awu. Wɔn a wɔtotɔn nnoɔma no nnwuma nso agu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman no ayɛ nsɛm a ɛkɔɔ so no maa nnipa a wɔwɔ ahoɔden no mu bi bɛdii awuduru na ɛkaeɛ sɛ ɛma nnwumakuw nketewa a wɔde yɛ adwuma no bɛbɔɔ asɛm no mu.</s>

en: Most of the customers had between five hundred Ghana cedis (GHS500.00) and twenty-seven thousand Ghana cedis (GHS27,000.00) locked up in the collapsed bank.
twi: Wɔn a wɔn ho aka no no mu dodoɔ no ara sika bɛyɛ GH¢500.00 kɔsi GH¢27,000.00 na akam wɔ sikakorabea a agu yi mu.
mt0: <pad> Nnipa pii a wɔde sika kɔɔ bank no mu no na wɔwɔ Ghana cedis bɛyɛ 500 ne Ghana cedis bɛyɛ 27,000.00 a wɔde kɔɔ bank no mu.</s>

en: Many demonstrations were staged particularly before the 2016 election by the victims to exert pressure on the then Opposition lawmaker to refund their locked-up fund. Some victims received their funds but many others have still not received theirs.
twi: Wɔn a wɔn sika akam no yɛɛ ɔyɛkyerɛ bebree ansa na 2016 abatoɔ no reba so sɛdeɛ wɔde gya bɛgu mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi so sɛ ɔde wɔn sika bɛma wɔn. Ebi nsa kaa wɔn sika nso dodoɔ no ara nsa anka wɔn sika.
mt0: <pad> Ɔyɛkyerɛ pii na wɔde too gua wɔ 2016 ɔmanpanin abatoɔ no mu sɛ wɔbɛma wɔn sika a wɔde kɔɔ so no. Mfeԑn bi nyaa wɔn sika no nanso nnipa pii nni wɔn sika no.</s>

en: Addressing the media in Koforidua, the aggrieved victims, numbering about twenty (20), chastised the lawmaker for failing to initiate plans of paying back customers.
twi: Wɔn a wɔn sika akam a wɔn dodoɔ bɛyɛ aduonu ne nsɛnkyerɛfoɔ redi nkɔmmɔ wɔ Koforidua no, wɔtwee mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi anim sɛ wantumi amfa nhyehyɛeɛ angu akwan mu antua wɔn sika amma wɔn.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no a wɔn ho yɛ hu no, bɛyɛ 20 na wɔkaeɛ sɛ ɔmfa nsɛm a wɔde boaa wɔn a wɔde sika kɔɔ so no nkaeɛ no, kyerɛɛ sɛ ɔmmoaa wɔn sika kɔɔ so no.</s>

en: According to them, several attempts to get their funds refunded have proven futile as they accused the MP of even failing to respond to their calls.
twi: Wɔn kyerɛ sɛ, wɔyɛ deɛ wɔbɛtumi ayɛ biara sɛ wɔn nsa bɛka wɔn sika nanso ankɔsi hwee. Wɔn sann nso de too dwa sɛ, sɛ wɔfrɛ mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi nso a, ɔmfa.
mt0: <pad> Ɛkaa wɔn ho sɛ, wɔyɛɛ nhyehyɛe ahorow sɛ wɔbɛnya wɔn sika no kɔɔ wɔn so nanso wɔn MP no antumi ankyerɛ wɔn nsɛm.</s>

en: A 72-year old trader Elizabeth Amoah, narrating her ordeal to the media, revealed the MP promised to refund her money after the 2020 general elections but has since refused to even respond to her calls.
twi: Elizabeth Amoah a ɔyɛ dwadini reka n’akosɛm akyerɛ nsɛnkyerɛfoɔ no, ɔde too dwa sɛ mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi hyɛɛ bɔ wɔto 2020 abatoɔ no wie a, ɔbɛtua wɔn sika ama wɔn nanso sɛ wɔfrɛ no tetefone so a, ɔmmfa.
mt0: <pad> Elizabeth Amoah, 72, a ɔyɛ adwumakuw a wadi mfe 72 no kaeɛ sɛ MP Ɔmanpanin Ɔmanpanin a ɔdi kan no deɛ ɔde ne sika bɛtuaa no ansa na ɔkɔ nkoguo mu no, kyerɛɛ sɛ ɔmpɛɛ sɛ ɔbɛgye ne sika a ɔde kɔɔ nkoguo mu no ansa na ɔkɔ nkoguo mu no.</s>

en: “I went to Begoro during the 2020 campaign season to demand my money but the MP apologized to me and promised to pay it soon after the election is over. It is sad to inform you that, the MP has not been picking my calls since after the elections, which he won,” she lamented.
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ, “Mekɔɔ Begoro sɛ ɔrekɔgye ne sika berɛ 2020 abatoɔ aporɔbɔ rekɔ so no na mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi paa no akyɛw hyɛɛ no bɔ sɛ sɛ wɔde abatoɔ no wie a, ɔde ne sika bɛma no. ɛyɛ awerɛho sɛ, yɛtoo aba no wieeɛ no a mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi dii nkonim no, mefrɛɛ mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi wɔ tetefone so maa no mfaa da.”
mt0: <pad> “Mekɔɔ Begoro wɔ 2020 nsɛm bere mu de kyerɛɛ me sika no na MP no kaaeɛ sɛ ɔbɛtua me sika no bere a ɔdii nhyiam no akyi. Nanso, mpɔtam panin no nni nsɛm a ɔde ma me firi mmerɛ a ɔdii nhyiam no akyi, a ɔdii nhyiam no.</s>

en: She added “how can I be defrauded by an MP of my GHC12,000.000 after so many years of savings and be walking freely as a lawmaker. I am appealing to President Akufo-Addo and the Speaker to speak to Amankwah Asiamah to refund my money or we shall gather ourselves at the Jubilee House and Parliament to demand our money”.
twi: ɔde kaa ho bio sɛ, “Adɛn nti na mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi bɛbɔ me apoo agye me GH¢12,000,000 a maboaboa ano afa ne ho adi. Mede dwaatoa redi ɔmampanin Akufo-Addo ne mmarahyɛbadwam kyeame sɛ wɔne Amankwah Asiamah nkasa ne ɔmfa me sika mma me anyɛ saa yɛbɛbɔ dɔmpem aba ɛubilee House ne mmarahyɛbadwafie abɛgye yɛn sika”.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ, "Sɛnea ɛbɛyɛ sɛ MP no betumi ama me GHC12,000,000.00 a ɛwɔ me sika mu nanso ɔkɔ so sɛ ɔmanpanin. Me ne President Akufo-Addo ne Speaker no rebɔ amanne sɛ Amankwah Asiamah bɛka sɛ ɔbɛgye me sika no anaa yɛbɛkɔ Jubilee House ne Parliament sɛ yɛbɛkyere sika a yɛde gye yɛn no".</s>

en: Another victim stated “we are pleading with President Akufo Addo and the speaker, Kennedy Agyapong to intervene I am a strong NPP supporter but this MP is treating us bad. During the 2020 election I went to Begoro with my daughter to see the MP he snubbed us, I cried why should we be treated like this ”
twi: Onipa foforɔ a ne sika nso akam nso de pii so sɛ, “yɛresrɛ ɔmampanin Akufo Addo ne mmarahyɛbadwam kyeame, Alban Bagbin sɛ wɔntu wɔn nan nsi asɛm yi so. Meyɛ NPP ni nso saa mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi ne yɛn nni no yie koraa. 2020 abatoɔ berɛ so no, me ne me babaa kɔɔ Begoro sɛ yɛrekɔhunu mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi nso wamfii yɛn. Mesuiɛ. Adɛn nti na ɛwɔ sɛ ɔyɛ yɛn sei?”
mt0: <pad> Another victim said “we are pleading with President Akufo Addo and the speaker, Kennedy Agyapong to intervene I am a strong NPP supporter but this MP is treating us bad. During the 2020 election I went to Begoro with my daughter to see the MP he snubbed us, I cried why should we be treated like this ”</s>

en: Several other traders shared their harrowing situation including collapsed marriages as a result of hardship the locked-up funds brought upon them.
twi: Adwadifoɔ a ɛka ho nso de wɔn akosɛn too dwa; ɛbi awareɛ a aguo ne ahokyerɛ a wɔnam mu ɛnam wɔn sika a aka mu no nti.

en: The Member of Parliament for Fanteakwa North Amankwah Asiamah who was the Chief Executive Officer of the collapsed Bank declined to comment on the latest agitations
twi: Fanteakwa North mmarahyɛbɛdwani, Amankwah Asiamah a ɔyɛ krakye paninpaa a ɔda saa sikakorabea a agu yi ano anka hwee amfa saa asɛm yi ho.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin a ɔwɔ Fanteakwa North Amankwah Asiamah a na ɔyɛɛ Bank no Chief Executive Officer nsɛe sɛ ɔbɛka sɛ ɔnim sɛ ɔbɛka sɛ ɔnim.</s>

en: But had earlier denied loaning deposits of the victims to sponsor Nana Akufo Addo’s campaign as alleged in 2012, hence the collapse as is peddled.
twi: Na mmom na wadi nkan aka sɛ ɛnyɛ nokorɛ sɛ ɔde nkorɔfoɔ sika a wɔde bɛguu sikakorabea hɔ no bɔɔ Nana Akufo Adoo dwetire sɛ ɔmfa ntoto 2012 abatoɔ ho nnoɔma a ɛmaa sikakorabea no guiiɛ.
mt0: <pad> But had earlier denied loaning deposits of the victims to sponsor Nana Akufo Addo’s campaign as alleged in 2012, hence the collapse as is peddled.</s>

en: According to the MP, it is also incorrect that the bank owes over 1,000 customers explaining that his outfit managed to refund deposits of the majority of the customers.
twi: Mmarahyɛbɛdwani yi kyerɛ sɛ, ɛnyɛ nokorɛ sɛ sikakorabea no de nnipa apem ka a ɔkyerɛ sɛ, sikakorabea no tuaa ne dodoɔ no ara sika maa wɔn.
mt0: <pad> According to the MP, it is also incorrect that the bank owes over 1,000 customers explaining that his outfit managed to refund deposits of the majority of the customers.</s>

en: The former Ranking Member for the Mines and Energy Committee of Parliament, Adam Mutawkilu has taunted Ghana’s Attorney General over the $170 million judgment debt case saying he would have won if the case was tried in Ghana.
twi: Adam Mutawkilu a na ɔka mmarahyɛbadwam fagudeɛ ne anyinam ahoɔden kɔmitee ho atwetwee aban lɔya panin wɔ $170,000,000 gyagyemɛnt dɛbet; ɔkyerɛ sɛ sɛ wɔkaa asɛm no wɔ Ghana a, nka ɔbɛdi nkonim.
mt0: <pad> Adam Mutawkilu, a na ɔyɛ Ghana’s Attorney General no nsɛm ho sɛ ɔbɛgye ne ho adi wɔ Ghana sɛ ɔbɛgye ne ho adi wɔ Ghana.</s>

en: According to him, the AG would have resorted to means and ways to win the case.
twi: ɔkyerɛ sɛ nka aban lɔya panin no bɛyɛ deɛ ɔbɛyɛ biara sɛ ɔbɛdi nkonim wɔ asɛm mu.
mt0: <pad> According to him, the AG would have resorted to all means and ways to win the case.</s>

en: “We looked at it meticulously and realized that it has met all the conditions and parliament approval was condition precedent. So for me, there was no need for government to have canceled the project. No! And they know that when it goes anywhere in the world, government will lose. Then probably they thought it will be handled in Ghana. Maybe they can flex their muscles to find their way out,” the former lawmaker told Francis Abban on the Morning Starr Thursday.
twi: mmarahyɛbɛdwani dadaa yi de too Francis Abban anim wɔ Morning Star dwumadie (na ɛyɛ Yawoadaɔ no so sɛ, “Yɛhwɛeɛ na yɛhunuu sɛ adi deɛ na ɛwɔ sɛ ɛdi soɔ nyinaa na afei nso mmarahyɛbadwafie nso agye atom. Me deɛ, na ɛho nhia sɛ aban bɛtwa saa nhyehyɛeɛ no mu. Daabi! Na wɔnim sɛ sɛ ɛkɔ baabiara wɔn wiase yi mu a, aban no bɛdi fo. Na wɔdwene sɛ sɛ wɔdi asɛm no wɔ Ghana, na wɔayɛ deɛ wɔbɛtumi ayɛ biara adi nkonim.”
mt0: <pad> 'We looked at it meticulously and realized that it has met all the conditions and parliament approval was condition precedent. So for me, there was no need for government to have canceled the project. No! And they know that when it goes anywhere in the world, government will lose. Then probably they thought it will be handled in Ghana. Maybe they can flex their muscles to find their way out'</s>

en: The Attorney General has however blamed the erstwhile Mahama administration for the situation.
twi: Aban lɔya panin de soboɔ no nyinaa abɔ Mahama amammuo.
mt0: <pad> Attorney General no de Mahama aban no sɛ ɔde saa tebea no bae.</s>

en: Background to the arbitration
twi: Asennie no ahyɛaseɛ
mt0: <pad> Arbitrary attributions</s>

en: The International Court of Arbitration in January 2021 awarded a cost of $134 million and an interest of $30 million against the Government of Ghana over the cancellation of an Emergency Power Agreement with GCGP limited.
twi: Ɔpɛpɔn 2021 mu na International Court of Arbitration bɔɔ Ghana aban no ka sɛ wɔntua $134,000,000 ne ɛho nsiho $30,000,000 sɛ wɔtwaa kɔntraagye a na ɔne GɔGP limited wɔ no mu.
mt0: <pad> International Court of Arbitration no wɔ Ɔpɛpɔn 2021 de $134 million ne $30 million sika a wɔde bɔɔ Ghana aban no so sɛ ɛbɛyɛ Emergency Power Contract a wɔde bɔɔ Ghana aban no so no.</s>

en: The Contract was cancelled under the former Energy Minister Boakye Agyarko as part of several other energy contracts cancelled by the NPP on the basis that the country did not need those power agreements.
twi: ɔsoafoɔ a na ɔhwɛ anyinam ahoɔden so, Boakye Agyarko aberɛ so na wɔtwa saa kɔntraagye wei ne anyinam ahoɔden kɔntraagye afoforɔ mu. NPP aban no kyerɛɛ sɛ na ɔman no nhia saa anyinam ahoɔden nhyehyɛeɛ yi.
mt0: <pad> Contract no ayɛɛ nsɛm wɔ Energy Minister Boakye Agyarko asɛm so sɛ ɛka nsɛm a ɛwɔ energy ho a NPP no ayɛɛ nsɛm wɔ ɔman no mu a ɛnhia saa power agreements no.</s>

en: The ruling by the International Court of Arbitration ordered the government to Ghana to pay to “GPGC the full value of the Early Termination Payment, together with Mobilization, Demobilization and preservation and maintenance costs in the amount of US$ 134,348,661, together also with interest thereon from 12 November 2018 until the date of payment, accruing daily and compounded monthly, at the rate of LIBOR for six-month US dollar deposits plus six per cent(6%).”
twi: Atemmuo a International Court of Arbitration de baeɛ no hyɛɛ Ghana aban sɛ wɔntua sika $134,348,661 ne ɛho nsiho biara firi bosome a ɛtɔ so du-baako no rekorɔ wɔ 2018 kɔpem nka kɔntraagye no bɛba awieeɛ mma GPGɔ.
mt0: <pad> Ghana aban no bɛtua “GPGC” Early Termination Payment, ne Mobilization, Demobilization ne preservation and maintenance costs a ɛyɛ US$134,348,661, ne interest a ɛkɔ so wɔ ɔkwan a ɛfiri 12 November 2018 kosi ɔkwan a wɔde bɛtua no, accruing daily and compounded monthly, at the rate of LIBOR for six-month US dollar deposits plus six per cent (6%).</s>

en: The Government of Ghana was also to pay GPGC an amount of “US$ 309,877.74 in respect of the Costs of the Arbitration, together with US$ 3,000,000 in respect of GPGC’s legal representation and the fees and expenses of its expert witness, together with interest on the aggregate amount of US$ 3,309,877.74 at the rate of LIBOR for three-month US dollar deposits, compounded quarterly.”
twi: Ghana aban no san nso tua $309,877/74 maa GPGC wɔ aka a ɛbaa asennie no ho, ne $3,000,000 maa GPGC wɔ ɛka a wɔbɔɔ no wɔ wɔn lɔyafoɔ ne adansefoɔ ho. Saa ka yi nyinaa hwire kɔɔ $3,309,877.74.
mt0: <pad> Ghana aban no nso bɛtua GPGC "US$ 309,877.74 wɔ Arbitration Costs ho, ne US$ 3,000,000 wɔ GPGC's legal representation ne fees ne expenses of its expert witness, ne interest wɔ US$ 3,309,877.74 at the LIBOR rate for three-month US dollar deposits, compounded quarterly."</s>

en: Residents in the Ajumako Ochiso Community of the Central region are excited beyond measure as a mammoth quantity of fish has appeared in their river [Ochi], which used to be just a source of drinking water for them.
twi: Wɔn a wɔte Ajumako Ochioso mpɔtam wɔ Mfimfini mantam mu no ani agye aborɔ so ɛsiane sɛ mpataa bebree na aba Oɔhi asubɔtene no mu a na ɛho na wɔnya wɔn nsuo a wɔnom.
mt0: <pad> Residents in the Ajumako Ochiso Community of the Central Region are excited beyond measure as a mammoth quantity of fish has appeared in their river [Ochi], which used to be just a source of drinking water for them.</s>

en: This happened after Thursday dawn’s downpour. According to the residents, the mystery was a blessing from the gods.
twi: Wei sii Yawoada ahomagye aberɛ nsuo tɔeɛ. Wɔn a wɔte kurom hɔ no kyerɛ sɛ, wei yɛ nhyira a wɔn nananom de adom wɔn.
mt0: <pad> Ɛkɔɔ so wɔ Thursday awieeɛ no. Sɛ nnipa a wɔwɔ hɔ no kae a, ɛyɛ ade a ɛfiri abosom no mu.</s>

en: Leaders in the community poured libations and opened up for inhabitants to apportion the bounty and take it home.
twi: mpaninfoɔ a wɔwɔ mpɔtam hɔ no guu nsa maa kwan sɛ wɔn a wɔte hɔ no bɛtumi akɔyi mpataa no bi de akɔ fie.
mt0: <pad> Leaders in the community poured libations and open up for inhabitants to apportion the bounty and take it home.</s>

en: Speaking to Kasapa FM’s central regional correspondent Yaw Boagyan, Wofa Yaw Obosu who used to work at the bank of the river narrated that this has never happened since he came into the area and he also believes it’s a blessing for the community.
twi: Wɔne Yaw Boagyan a ɛyɛ Kasapa FM amannebɔfoɔ ne Wofa Yaw Obosu a na ɔyɛ adwuma wɔ asubɔntene no ano kyerɛɛ sɛ, biribi sei nsii da firii mmerɛ ɔbaa kurom hɔ na ɔgye di sɛ, ɛyɛ nhyira ma mantam no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ɔbɛn a ɛkɔ so no, Wofa Yaw Obosu a ɔyɛ adwuma wɔ asubɔnten no nkyɛn kaa sɛ ɛyɛ ade a ɛyɛ nkuran ma nkuro no na ɔkyerɛ sɛ ɛyɛ nsakrae ma nkuro no.</s>

en: According to him, they will send some of the fishes to the market for sale. “Since the fishes appeared at the river bank, I have been able to employ over twenty youth to work for me to process for sale at the Mankessim, Kasoa, markets.”
twi: ɔkyerɛɛ sɛ wɔde mpataa no bi bɛkɔ dwa so akɔtɔn. “Berɛ a mpataa baa asubɔtene no mu, mafa mmaubunu a wɔborɔ aduonu adwuma a wɔtɔ mpataa no wɔ Mankessin ne Kasoa dwom.”
mt0: <pad> According to him, they will send some of the fishes to the market for sale. “Since the fishes appeared at the river bank, I have been able to employ over twenty youths to work for me to process for sale at the Mankessim, Kasoa, markets.”</s>

en: “This is beyond my understanding since something of this nature has never happened in the Ajumako Ochiso Community.”
twi: “ɛborɔ me nteaseɛ so ɛsiane sɛ biribi sei nsii da wɔ Aɛumako Oɔhiso mpɔtam yi da.”
mt0: <pad> “Eno kɔ akyi sɛ m'adwene mu, esiane sɛ adeɛ a ɛte saa no nni Ajumako Ochiso Community no mu.</s>

en: Meanwhile, some of the residents who came went the scene also appealed to the Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture to come and assist them in terms of providing them with tricycles to be able to transport the fishes to the market.
twi: Afei, wɔn a wɔte hɔ no de adesrɛdeɛ too asoeɛ a ɛhyɛ mpataa ne nsuom sɛm so sɛ wɔmmoa wɔn na wɔmma wɔn kaa a wɔde mpataa no bɛgu mu akɔ dwa so.
mt0: <pad> Ɛnanso, nnipa bi a wɔkɔɔ saa beae no mu no nso de wɔn adwene too Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture sɛ ɛbɛba bɛboa wɔn na wɔatumi atwe nsuo no kɔtɔn no mu.</s>

en: “We don’t have job to do in the Ajumako Ochiso Community here so this will enable us to be employed to get money to take care of our children’s education and household. We are therefore calling on authorities to come and assist us to address the challenges we are facing in the Ajumako Ochiso Community as regards employment,” a resident appealed.
twi: Onipa baako a ɔte mpɔtam hɔ de too dwa sɛ, “Yɛnni adwuma biara wɔ Aɛumako Oɔhiso mpɔtam yi mu nti wei bɛboa yɛn ama yɛanya adwuma ayɛ anya sika ahwɛ yɛn mma wɔ sukuu ne fie. Yɛde adesrɛdeɛ reto mpaninfoɔ anim sɛ wɔmmra mmɛboa yɛn na wɔsi adwumayɛ haw a yɛrefam wɔ Aɛumako Oɔhioso mpatam yi.”
mt0: <pad> “Yɛnnni adwuma wɔ Ajumako Ochiso Community no nti ɛbɛma yɛn anya adwuma na yɛbɛtumi ayi sika akɔgye yɛn mmofra adesua ne yɛn abusua. Yɛrebɔ aman mpaninfo kɔboa yɛn ma yɛnya adwuma sɛdeɛ ɛbɛyɛ a yɛbɛtumi ayi yɛn mmofra adesua ne yɛn abusua,” ɔmanpanin bi kaa.</s>

en: The Assembly Member of the Ajumako Ochiso South Maxwell Mensah also appealed to the Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture and other government to assist the community members in terms of providing logistics to be able to fish for more fishes in the river for the youth to be employed.
twi: Asembele mɛmba a wɔwɔ Ajumako Ochioso anaafoɔ, Maxwell Mensah de adesrɛdeɛ too asoeɛ a ɛhwɛ nsuom nam ne nsuom so ne aban sɛ wɔmmɛyɛ wɔn a wɔte mpɔtam no mmoa na wɔnnya akadeɛ a ɛbɛboa wɔn ama wɔayi mpataa wɔ asubɔntene no mu sɛdeɛ ɛbɛyɛ a mmabunu no bɛnya adwuma ayɛ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin a ɔwɔ Ajumako Ochiso South Maxwell Mensah nso de nsɛm too ɔman panin no ho sɛ wɔmma logistics sɛ wɔbɛtumi ahyɛ nnuane pii wɔ asubɔnten no mu na ama nnipa a wɔwɔ hɔ no anya adwuma.</s>

en: The Executive Director for the Institute of Energy Security, Nana Amoasi VII, has taken a swipe at the Attorney General, Godfred Dame, describing him as negligent for his failure to defend Ghana on the $170 million judgment debt awarded to power company, The Ghana Power Generation Company (GCGP).
twi: Kwankyerɛfoɔ a ɔda Institute of Energy Security ano, Nana Amoasi VII akyerɛ n’adwene akyerɛ aban lɔya panin, Godfred Dame, a ɔkyerɛ sɛ wanyɛ n’adwuma yie ama Ghana aban no bɛtoa $170,000,000 ama Ghana Power Generation company(GCGP).
mt0: <pad> Nana Amoasi VII, Executive Director of the Institute of Energy Security, has taken a swipe at the Attorney General, Godfred Dame, describing him as negligent for his failure to defend Ghana on the $170 million judgment debt awarded to power company, The Ghana Power Generation Company (GCGP).</s>

en: In an interview on the Morning Starr on Thursday, Nana Amoasi VII called on the Attorney General to account to Ghanaians why he failed to appeal the $170 million judgment debt in time.
twi: ɔretwetwe nkɔmmɔ wɔ Morning Starr dwumadie no so da Yawoada no, Nana Amoasi VII de too dwa sɛ aban lɔya panin mmɛkyerɛ Ghanafoɔ sɛnti wankɔ dwanetoa ɛfa $170,000,000 no ho.
mt0: <pad> Na ɔde nsɛm no kyerɛɛ Morning Starr no wɔ Thursday, Nana Amoasi VII de Ghanafoɔ no kɔmmɔ ne ho asɛm sɛ ɔbɛka Ghanafoɔ no sɛ ɔyɛɛ adeɛ a ɛyɛ $170 million judgment debt no ntɛm.</s>

en: “We had an opportunity to go and appeal against the decision and we chose to use Covid-19 and election as excuses. The Attorney General was negligent as well. He didn’t act well. He could have defended us better so we should look into it.”
twi: “Na yɛwɔ ho kwan sɛ yɛkɔ asɛm yi ho dwanetoa na mmom yɛde COVID-19 ne abatoɔ yiyii yɛn ho ano. Aban lɔya panin no anyɛ n’adwama yie. Wanyɛ deɛ na ɛwɔ sɛ ɔyɛ. Nka ɔbɛtumi abɔ yɛn akyiridom yie nti ɛyɛ sɛ yɛhwehwɛ mu.”
mt0: <pad> “Yɛnni ɔkwan a yɛbɛkɔ sɛdeɛ wɔbɛkyerɛ no nanso yɛde Covid-19 ne abatoɔ no yɛɛ asɛm. Ɔmanpanin no yɛɛ adwuma a ɛyɛ den. Ɔmanpanin no yɛɛ adwuma a ɛyɛ den. Ɔmanpanin no yɛɛ adwuma a ɛyɛ den. en: His comments come after the Commercial Court in London rejected a late appeal from Ghana against a judgement debt award of US$170 million in favour of power contractor, The Ghana Power Generation Company (GCGP).
twi: ɔde saa nsɛm yi too dwa berɛ ɔommerɔial Court a ɛwɔ London bɔɔ Ghana aban no asɛm guiiɛ, ɛfa $170,000,000 sika a ɛwɔ sɛ ɔtua ma Ghana Power Generation companyno.
mt0: <pad> Ghana akɔsɛe wɔn adehye a wɔde bɛyɛ US$170 million sika a wɔde bɛyɛ Ghana Power Generation Company (GCGP) no.</s>

en: According to the London Court, the government of Ghana failed to apply and set aside the January 26, 2021 decision of the London-based United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) Tribunal.
twi: London kɔɔto kyerɛ sɛ, Ghana aban amfa United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) Tribunal no anni dwuma na ɔbuu n’ani guu so.
mt0: <pad> According to the London Court, the government of Ghana failed to apply and set aside the January 26, 2021 decision of the London-based United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) Tribunal.</s>

en: The court in a ruling on Wednesday, June 8, refused to grant the government of Ghana an extension to apply to set aside the award – adding that the state’s grounds for challenging it were “intrinsically weak”.
twi: Kɔɔto no atemmuo ɔde too dwa Wukuada, Kɔtɔnima da a ɛtɔ so nwɔtwe no hyɛɛ Ghana aban no sɛ ɔntua sika no ɛsiane sɛ nsɛm a wɔgyina so no mu yɛ mmerɛ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no de nsɛm a wɔde too gua no, June 8, nkaeɛ Ghana aban no sɛ ɔbɛbɔ mmɔden sɛ ɔbɛkyere ɔfa no mu – akɔkaeɛ sɛ Ghana aban no nsɛm a wɔde too gua no yɛ "intrinsically weak".</s>

en: The government through its lawyer Godfred Dame had attempted to hide behind the 2020 general election and the COVID-19 pandemic as excuses for the delay, but their excuses were dismissed by the London court.
twi: Aban no lɔya, Godfred Dame kyerɛ sɛ 2020 abatoɔ no ne COVID-19 na ɛmaa wɔtwentwɛn wɔn nna ase nso London kɔɔto no bɔɔ ne nsɛm yi guiɛ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no, ɛwɔ ɔmanpanin no lawyer Godfred Dame, de n'akyi bɛkae sɛ 2020 general election ne COVID-19 pandemic nanso wɔn akyi no akɔ so wɔ London court no mu.</s>

en: GPGC was represented before the court by Charles Kimmins QC and Mark Tushingham, where Ghana was said to have been too late to challenge the decision against it.
twi: Charles Kimmins Qɔ ne Mark Tushingham a wɔyɛ lɔya ma GPGɔ wɔ kɔɔto nsɛm yi mu kyerɛ sɛ Ghana aban no kyeree ansa na wɔrekɔ saa asɛm yi ho dwanetoa.
mt0: <pad> GPGC a wɔde yɛɛ adwuma no kɔɔ asɛnnibea no anim no yɛ Charles Kimmins QC ne Mark Tushingham, Ghana a wɔkae sɛ ɛbɛyɛɛ too late sɛ ɛbɛkyeree nsunsuansoɔ a wɔde sii no adi.</s>

en: Ghana had used Khawar Qureshi QC of Serle Court and Volterra Fietta, having initially retained Omnia Strategy. In the arbitration, GPGC, used Three Crowns and Ghanaian firm, Kimathi & Partners, along with damages experts from FTI Consulting.
twi: Ghana aban no de Khawar Qureshi Qɔ a ɛwɔ Serle kɔɔto ne Volteraa Fietta dii dwuma aberɛ wɔde Omnia Strategy nso kaa ho. Asennie no mu no, GPGɔ de Three ɔrowns ne Ghana dwumakuo Kimathi & Partners ne FTI ɔonsulting nso na ɛdii dwuma.
mt0: <pad> Ghana de Khawar Qureshi QC of Serle Court and Volterra Fietta, a wɔde Omnia Strategy no adi dwuma. Wɔ nsɛm no mu no, GPGC, de Three Crowns ne Ghanaian firm, Kimathi & Partners, a wɔde damages experts fi FTI Consulting.</s>

en: Ghana also had representation from the attorney general’s office and Amofa & Partners in Accra.
twi: Ghana de nnipa a wɔfiri aban lɔya panin akakye ne Amofa & Partners a ɛwɔ Nkran no kɔeɛ.
mt0: <pad> Ghana nso na wɔwɔ ɔmanpanin no adwumakuw ne Amofa & Partners wɔ Accra.</s>

en: The three-member arbitration tribunal chaired by John Beechey, a former President of the International Criminal Court’s Court of Arbitration, and co-chaired by Prof Albert Fiadjoe, a Ghanaian academic, sided with the power producer and awarded almost US$170 million, including interest.
twi: Nnipa baasa a na wɔredi asɛm yi a na wɔn titenafoɔ ne John Beeɔhey, ɔkandifoɔ a na ɔda International ɔriminal Court of Arbitration ano, ne Prof Albert Fiadɛoe a ɔyɛ Ghanani a ɔyɛ ɔbenfoɔ maa kwan sɛ Ghana aban no ntua $170,000,000 a nsiho ka ho.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin a wɔn ho yɛ ɔha na wɔde sika bɛyɛ US$170 million, ɛka ho ne sɛ ɛho yɛ adehye, kyerɛ sɛ ɛnnim.</s>

en: Out of the total, U$134.35 million represents the early termination payment claim, which itself is made up of US $69.36 million as an early termination fee, US$58.49 million for mobilisation costs, US$6.46 million as demobilisation cost and US$32,448 as preservation and maintenance cost.
twi: Dɔla no ɔpepem 134.35 yɛ sɛ wɔtwaa kɔntraagye no mu a na ɔpepem 69.36 yɛ sɛ wɔtwaa kɔntraagye no mu ntɛm, ɔpepem 58.49 yɛ mɔbilaisehyin ka, ɔpempem 6.46 yɛ dimɔbilaisehyin ka ɛnna ɔpepem 32,448 yɛ ahobammɔ ka.
mt0: <pad> Ɛfiri ɔman no mu, U$134.35 million yɛ early termination payment claim, a ɛwɔ US $69.36 million sɛ early termination fee, US$58.49 million sɛ mobilisation costs, US$6.46 million sɛ demobilisation costs ne US$32,448 sɛ preservation and maintenance costs.</s>

en: The tribunal also awarded US$614,353.86 against the country as the cost of the tribunal, and costs of US$3 million against Ghana, being the legal fees expended by the GPGC during the arbitration.
twi: Kɔɔto no san nso bɔɔ Ghana aban no ka dɔla no 614,353.86 sɛ ɛyɛ asennie no ka ɛnna dɔla no ɔpepem mmiɛnsa sɛ ɛyɛ ka GPGɔ bɔɔ no wɔn alɔyafoɔ ne asennie no ka.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman no nso bɛgye US$614,353.86 sɛ ɔman no nsɛm ho, ne US$3 million sɛ Ghana nsɛm ho, a ɛyɛ GPGC legal fees a wɔde dii nsɛm no mu bere a ɔman no kɔɔ so.</s>

en: Major highlights of the tribunal’s decision included the fact that the Ahenkora Committee which recommended the termination of the contract did not have sufficient ground in coming to the conclusion that the GPGC was entitled to only $US18 million in early termination fees.
twi: Nsɛntitire a kɔɔto no de too dwa ne sɛ, Ahenkora Kɔmihyin a wɔkyerɛɛ sɛ wɔntwa kɔntraagye no mu no annya nnyinasoɔ papa biara a wɔde too dwa sɛ, sɛ wɔtwa kɔntraagye no mu a, ɛwɔ sɛ wɔtua $18,000,000 pɛ na ɛma GPGɔ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkwan a wɔde dii no kyerɛɛ sɛ Ahenkora Committee a ɔboaa sɛ wɔbɛtwee contract no adi no nni adeɛ a ɛma ɛyɛ den sɛ ɛbɛka sɛ GPGC bɛnya $US18 million ansa na ɛbɛtwee contract no.</s>

en: The tribunal, in dismissing Ghana’s case, delved into the basis for terminating the contract, stating that the evidence before it indicated that “GPGC did have a building permit for the Blue Ocean Site issued by the Kpone-Katamanso District Assembly on August 15, 2017.”
twi: Kɔɔto no rebɔ Ghana aban no asɛm no aguo no, wɔdɔɔ asukɔ kɔɔ kɔntraagye a wɔtwaa mu no kyerɛɛ sɛ nnyinasoɔ a wɔgyinaa so de twaa kɔntraagye no mu no kyerɛɛ sɛ GPGɔ wɔ tumi nkrataa a Kpone-Katamanso mansini asɛmbele no dee maa wɔn fa Blue Oɔean asase no wɔ ɔsanaa da a ɛtɔ so du-num wɔ afe 2017 mu.
mt0: <pad> Ghana no nsɛm no mu, ɔmanpanin no de kɔkɔbɔ a ɛkyerɛ sɛ "GPGC nni adeyɛ krataa ma Blue Ocean Site a wɔde sii no firi Kpone-Katamanso District Assembly no bɛyɛ August 15, 2017".</s>

en: “GoG [The government] has not been able to adduce any statute or regulation, including the Energy Commission Act, which addresses the requirement for any such additional construction permit,” the Tribunal ruled.
twi: Kɔɔto no buaa sɛ, Ghana aban no annya adansidie biara a Energy Commission Act ka ho a ɛma wɔnya kɔntrahyin pɛɛmɛt.
mt0: <pad> “GoG [The government] ntumi mfa ɔkwan biara anaa ɛho nsakraeɛ, te sɛ Energy Commission Act, a ɛkyerɛ sɛ ɛho hia sɛ wɔde adeɛ a ɛbɛyɛ adwuma no kɔ so,” Ɔmanpanin no kaa.</s>

en: “On the basis of the record as it now stands, it is apparent that even as Dr. Ahenkorah [Energy Commission Executive Secretary at the time] was putting up further hurdles over which he required GPGC to jump in pursuit of its provisional generation license in November 2017, the Minister of Energy was about to seek the approval of the Ghanaian Parliament of a decision to terminate the EPA along with a number of other PPAs, based upon the Report of the PPA Committee chaired by Dr. Ahenkorah,” it said.
twi: Kɔɔto no de too dwa sɛ, “Sɛdeɛ nnoɔma teɛ no Dr. Ahenkorah (ogyahoɔden kɔmihyin twerɛtwerɛfoɔ paninɔ maa akwansideɛ baeɛ sɛdeɛ GPGɔ bɛdi anim akɔgye tumi nkrataa wɔ Obubuo, 2017 mu. Na ɔsoafoɔ a ɔhwɛ ogyahoɔden gyina PPA Kɔmitee a Dr. Ahenkorah da ano no mmuaeɛ a wɔde baeɛ no so retwɛn agye mmuaeɛ afiri Ghana mmarahyɛbadwafie sɛdeɛ ɛbɛyɛ a ɔbɛgu atenaeɛ bammɔ adwuma (EPAɔ ne PPAs ahodoɔ.”
mt0: <pad> Ɔkwantuni no so, ɛyɛ anika sɛ Dr. Ahenkorah [Energy Commission Executive Secretary at the time] rekɔɔ so de nsunsuansoɔ a ɛhyɛɛ GPGC sɛ ɛbɛgyina wɔ ɛno nti ɛbɛyɛɛ sɛ ɛbɛkɔ so sɛ ɛbɛnya Provisional Generation License in November 2017, na Energy Minister no rekɔɔ so sɛ ɔbɛbɔ Ghanaian Parliament no mmɔden sɛ ɔbɛkyerɛ sɛ ɔbɛtwe EPA ne PPAs afoforɔ no mu, ɛwɔ Report of the PPA Committee chaired by Dr. Ahenkorah, ɛkaeɛ.</s>

en: Under British law, the government had 28 days to challenge the tribunal’s decision. However, it went to sleep only to appear in court three days to the expiry of the deadline to ask for an extension.

en: Omnia Strategy, a British law firm, made the case for extension and asked for 56 days—twice the allowed grace period.
twi: Omnia Strategy a ɛyɛ Britain mmara adwumakuo srɛɛ sɛ wɔmfa nna aduonum nsia nka mmerɛ no ho. Wei yɛ mmerɛ a na wɔwɔ sɛ wɔkɔ asɛm no ho dwanetoa no saa mprenu.
mt0: <pad> Omnia Strategy, a British adwumakuw a wɔde nsɛm kyerɛ no, de ɔkwan ma ɛkɔɔ so na wɔbɔɔ mmɔden sɛ wɔbɛma nna 56—twice the grace period a wɔtumi de ma.</s>

en: However, the court set March 8, 2021, for the Government to file the processes to challenge the Tribunal’s decision in January. But again, the government took a long nap until April 1, 2021, before filing. This time, another British law firm, Volterra Fietta, had instructions from the government to begin the process.
twi: Kɔɔto no tuu ɔbenem da a ɛtɔ so nwɔtwe, 2021 sii hɔ sɛ aban no bɛtumi ahyɛ wɔn dwanetoa wɔ kɔɔto no atemmuo a wɔde too dwa wɔ ɔpɛpɔn no mu ase. Bio, aban no tenaa hɔ saa kɔsi Oforisuo da a ɛdi kan, 2021 ansa na wɔrehyɛ dwanetoa no ase. Saa berɛ yi, Britain mmara dwumakuo Volteraa Fietta nyaa nteeɛ firii aban no hɔ sɛ wɔnhyɛ dwanetoa no ase.
mt0: <pad> Nanso, ɔmanpanin no de March 8, 2021, sɛ wɔbɛfa nsɛm a wɔde bɔ Ɔmanpanin no kwaadu a ɛwɔ January mu no adi. Nanso, ɔmanpanin no kɔɔ so ara kɔsi April 1, 2021, ansa na wɔde nsɛm no adi.</s>

en: The law firm, which tagged itself as the only dedicated public international law firm in the world, explained that the new Attorney General, Godfred Yeboah Dame, had only been sworn in on March 5, and the firm received the directive to represent Ghana 10 days later.
twi: Saa mmara dwumakuo yi a wɔbɔ wɔn ho nsammrane sɛ wɔne dwumakuo a aman a ɛwɔ wiase yi mu nyinaa nsɛm ma wɔn kyerɛɛ mu sɛ, nna du akyi a wɔde aban lɔya panin, Godfred Yeboah Dame dii adeɛ ɔbenem da a ɛtɔ so nnum, na aban no yii no asotire sɛ wɔnhyɛ dwanetoa no ase.
mt0: <pad> Ghana's new Attorney General, Godfred Yeboah Dame, was sworn in on March 5, and the firm received the directive to represent Ghana 10 days later.</s>

en: But ruling on the matter on June 8, 2021, the court had no sympathies. It said the excuses were unreasonable and “intrinsically weak.”
twi: Kɔɔto no de n’atemmuo reto dwa wɔ Kɔtɔnima da a ɛtɔ so nwɔtwe, 2021, wɔkyerɛ sɛ nsɛm a wɔde reto dwa no nyinaa mu ntɔ asom na ɛmu nyɛ du.
mt0: <pad> Ɛnnim sɛ ɔbɛkaa no wɔ June 8, 2021, nanso ɔmanpanin no nni nkabom. Ɔkaa sɛ excuses no yɛ unreasonable na ɛyɛ "intrinsically weak."</s>

en: The presiding judge, Justice Butcher did not hold back.
twi: ɔtɛmmuafoɔ, Justice Butɔher atwentwɛn ne nan ase koraa.
mt0: <pad> Ɔsahene a ɔdi kan, Justice Butcher nni nsɛm a ɔkaeɛ.</s>

en: The judge said the government’s delay was “significant and substantial” as its request for a second extension had come 38 days after the statutory deadline and 27 days after the first extension expired, the Global Arbitration Review (GAR) reported.
twi: Global Arbitration Review (GARɔ de too dwa sɛ, ɔtɛmmuafoɔ no kyerɛ sɛ aban twentwɛnsoɔ no no yɛ sɛgnefekant ɛnna ɛsan nso yɛ substenhyeaa ne sɛn nti sɛ wɔn dwanetoa no hyɛɛ aseɛ nnan aduasa-wɔtwe apa ho na afei nso nnan aduonu nson berɛ a ntomu a ɛdi kan no atwam no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔsahene no kaa sɛ ɔman no nkɔmmɔ no yɛ "significant and substantial" esiane sɛ ɔde nsa hyɛɛ sɛ ɛbɛbɔ mmɔden sɛ ɛbɛbɔ mmɔden a edi kan no mu 38 da na ɛtɔ so 27 da bere a ɛtɔ so 1 no awiee.</s>

en: He noted that the large sum of money involved in the arbitration was not enough grounds for the appeal to take as long as it did.
twi: ɔkyerɛɛ sɛ, sika twetweredie a ɛwɔ asennie no mu no mma no kwan ma dwanetoa mma mu sɛdeɛ ɛsiiɛ no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ sika a ɛwɔ nkitahodie no mu no yɛ ɔkwan a ɛbɛma wɔn nsa aka nkitahodie no ntɛm sɛ wɔde bɛtwa mmerɛ a ɛte saa.</s>

en: “The fact that the Attorney General had not been sworn until March 5 did not mean the government was unable to act in the meantime, the judge said.
twi: ɔde kaa ho sɛ, ɛfam ho sɛ ɔbenem da a ɛtɔ so nnum ansa na wɔde aban lɔya panin dii adeɛ no, ɛma aban no ho kwan wɔmfa mmerɛ a wɔde mma wɔn no nni dwuma.

en: Background to the arbitration
twi: Asennie no ahyɛaseɛ
mt0: <pad> Arbitrary attributions</s>

en: The International Court of Arbitration in January 2021 awarded a cost of $134 million and an interest of $30 million against the Government of Ghana over the cancellation of an Emergency Power Agreement with GCGP limited.
twi: Ɔ pɛpɔn 2021 mu na International Court of Arbitration bɔɔ Ghana aban no ka sɛ wɔntua $134,000,000 ne ɛho nsiho $30,000,000 sɛ wɔtwaa kɔntraagye a na ɔne GɔGP limited wɔ no mu.
mt0: <pad> International Court of Arbitration no wɔ Ɔpɛpɔn 2021 de $134 million ne $30 million sika a wɔde bɔɔ Ghana aban no so sɛ ɛbɛyɛ Emergency Power Contract a wɔde bɔɔ Ghana aban no so no.</s>

en: The Contract was cancelled under the former Energy Minister Boakye Agyarko as part of several other energy contracts cancelled by the NPP on the basis that the country did not need those power agreements.
twi: ɔsoafoɔ a na ɔhwɛ anyinam ahoɔden so, Boakye Agyarko aberɛ so na wɔtwa saa kɔntraagye wei ne anyinam ahoɔden kɔntraagye afoforɔ mu. NPP aban no kyerɛɛ sɛ na ɔman no nhia saa anyinam ahoɔden nhyehyɛeɛ yi.
mt0: <pad> Contract no ayɛɛ nsɛm wɔ Energy Minister Boakye Agyarko asɛm so sɛ ɛka nsɛm a ɛwɔ energy ho a NPP no ayɛɛ nsɛm wɔ ɔman no mu a ɛnhia saa power agreements no.</s>

en: The ruling by the International Court of Arbitration ordered the government to Ghana to pay to “GPGC the full value of the Early Termination Payment, together with Mobilization, Demobilization and preservation and maintenance costs in the amount of US$ 134,348,661, together also with interest thereon from 12 November 2018 until the date of payment, accruing daily and compounded monthly, at the rate of LIBOR for six-month US dollar deposits plus six per cent(6%).”
twi: Atemmuo a International Court of Arbitration de baeɛ no hyɛɛ Ghana aban sɛ wɔntua sika $134,348,661 ne ɛho nsiho biara firi bosome a ɛtɔ so du-baako no rekorɔ wɔ 2018 kɔpem nka kɔntraagye no bɛba awieeɛ mma GPGɔ.
mt0: <pad> Ghana aban no bɛtua “GPGC” Early Termination Payment, ne Mobilization, Demobilization ne preservation and maintenance costs a ɛyɛ US$134,348,661, ne interest a ɛkɔ so wɔ ɔkwan a ɛfiri 12 November 2018 kosi ɔkwan a wɔde bɛtua no, accruing daily and compounded monthly, at the rate of LIBOR for six-month US dollar deposits plus six per cent (6%).</s>

en: The Government of Ghana was also to pay GPGC an amount of “US$ 309,877.74 in respect of the Costs of the Arbitration, together with US$ 3,000,000 in respect of GPGC’s legal representation and the fees and expenses of its expert witness, together with interest on the aggregate amount of US$ 3,309,877.74 at the rate of LIBOR for three-month US dollar deposits, compounded quarterly.”
twi: Ghana aban no san nso tua $309,877/74 maa GPGC wɔ aka a ɛbaa asennie no ho, ne $3,000,000 maa GPGɔ wɔ ɛka a wɔbɔɔ no wɔ wɔn lɔyafoɔ ne adansefoɔ ho. Saa ka yi nyinaa hwire kɔɔ $3,309,877.74.
mt0: <pad> Ghana aban no nso bɛtua GPGC "US$ 309,877.74 wɔ Arbitration Costs ho, ne US$ 3,000,000 wɔ GPGC's legal representation ne fees ne expenses of its expert witness, ne interest wɔ US$ 3,309,877.74 at the LIBOR rate for three-month US dollar deposits, compounded quarterly."</s>

en: A baby has been reportedly washed away in Sawaba in Kumasi following the Wednesday evening rains in the Ashanti regional capital.
twi: Wɔde ato dwa sɛ, nsu kɛseɛ a ɛtɔeɛ wɔ Kumasi, Asante mantam kuropɔn no mu afa akwadaa ketewa bi wɔ Sawaba.

en: The baby was traveling with his parents in a tricycle when they got stuck in a flood causing the tricycle to tip over.
twi: Na saa akwadaa ketewa yi ne n’awofoɔ retu kwan a na wɔte pragia mu. ɛnam nsuyiri no nti, pragia no buu faa so.
mt0: <pad> Baby no na ɔrekɔ ne mmofra ne wɔn awofo wɔ tricycle bere a wɔbɛtɔɔ nsuo mu nti tricycle no tipɛɛ.</s>

en: Residents in the community, according to reports, moved in to save the parents but could not find the baby as he was washed away by the flood.
twi: Wɔkyerɛ sɛ, wɔn a wɔte mpɔtam mu hɔ no tɔɔ nsuom no yii awofoɔ no na mmom wɔanhunu akwadaa no ɛsiane sɛ na nsuo no de no kɔ.
mt0: <pad> Residents in the community, according to reports, moved in to save the parents but could not find the baby as he was washed away by the flood.</s>

en: “The body of the baby who was washed away hasn’t been found. The parents are not taking it easy at all. When it rains, it’s difficult to use the Sawaba road. The gutters become flooded so we don’t know why the tricycle rider tried using the road that led to the death of the 1-yr-old baby,” a resident told Francis Abban on the Morning Starr Thursday.
twi: Wɔn a wɔte mpɔtam no mu baako de too Francis Abban anim wɔ Morning Star Thursday dwumadie no so sɛ, “Wɔnhunuu akwadaa a nsuo no faa no no amu. Asɛm yi aha n’awofoɔ ankasa. Sɛ nsuo tɔ a, ɛyɛ den sɛ wobɛfa Sawaba kwan no so. Nsuo yiri fa gɔta no mu nti yɛnnim deɛ nti a deɛ na ɔreka pragia no faa saa kwan no so a ɛmaa abɔfra a wadi afe no hweree ne nkwa.”

The gutters become flooded so we don’t know why the tricycle rider tried using the road that led to the death of the 1-year-old baby,” a resident told Francis Abban on the Morning Starr Thursday.</s>

en: Other reports also say the convoy of President Akufo-Addo which was returning from the Upper East region got stuck in the flood.

en: The Minister for National Security Albert Kan Dapaah has revealed details surrounding the forceful eviction of former Ashanti Regional Security Coordinator DCOP Opare-Addo (rtd) from office by some National Security operatives.
twi: ɔsoafoɔ a ɔhwɛ ɔman bammɔ adwuma so, Albert Kan Dapaah akyerɛ deɛ nti a watu Asante mantam mu bammɔ adwuma ntotoeɛfoɔ, DCOP Opare-Addo (rtdɔ afiri n’adeɛ so.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman panin Albert Kan Dapaah kyerɛɛ sɛ ɔde nsa aka former Ashanti Regional Security Coordinator DCOP Opare-Addo (rtd) firi ne biribi mu no ɛfa sɛnea National Security operatives de no fiii ne biribi mu.</s>

en: According to Kan Dapaah, the move became necessary after several attempts to get the security Coordinator to vacate post after the termination of his appointment proved futile.

en: The ejected coordinator told Starr News he was evicted by members of NPP affiliated vigilante group, Delta Force, who assaulted him in the process for failing to do their bidding in the region.
twi: Bammɔ adwuma ntotoeɛfoɔ a wɔtuu no adeɛ so no de too Star News anim sɛ, NPP kuo bi a wɔfrɛ wɔn Delta Forɔe tiatiaa ne fahodie so ɛsiane sɛ wanyɛ deɛ na wɔrehwehwɛ sɛ ɔbɛyɛ wɔ mantam no mu.
mt0: <pad> Nnipa a wɔde Delta Force yɛ vigilante group no, Delta Force, na wɔkyeree no wɔ ɔkwan so no mu, Starr News kaeɛ.</s>

en: But answering questions from South Dayi MP Rockson-Nelson Dafeamekpo, the national security minister explained the men dispatched were national security operatives.
twi: Aberɛ ɔsoafoɔ a ɔhwɛ ɔman bammɔ adwuma so ne South Dayi mmarahyɛbɛdwani, Roɔkson-Nelson Dafeamekpo redi nkɔmmɔ no, ɔde too dwa sɛ ɔman bammufoɔ adwumayɛfoɔ na wɔdii saa dwuma no.
mt0: <pad> Nanso ɛwɔ South Dayi MP Rockson-Nelson Dafeamekpo no ase no, national security minister no kaa sɛ nnipa a wɔdekɔɔ hɔ no yɛ national security operatives.</s>

en: He, however, refused to disclose reasons for the termination of the appointment of Mr. Opare-Addo insisting the use of force was necessary under the circumstances.
twi: Na mmom, wankyerɛ sɛnti a wɔtuu Mr. Opare-Addo adeɛ so a ɔrekyerɛ sɛ na ɛho hia sɛ wɔde ɔhyɛ tu no adeɛ so.
mt0: <pad> Ɔdeɛ, nanso, ɔnhyɛɛ aseɛ sɛ ɔbɛkyerɛ nteaseɛ a ɔde kɔtwee Mr. Opare-Addo no ho sɛ ɛho hia sɛ wɔde tumi di dwuma wɔ saa tebeaeɛ yi mu.</s>

en: “He [Opare-Addo] was on a three-year contract to serve as the Ashanti regional security liaison officer after the expiration of an initial two-year contract which began on January 5th, 2018. His new appointment took effect from January 1, 2020, and was to expire on December 31, 2022.”
twi: Na Opare-Addo de ne nsa ahyɛ mfeɛ mmiɛnsa kɔntraagye ase sɛ ɔbɛyɛ Asante mantam mu bammɔ adwuma ntotoeɛfoɔ berɛ ne mfeɛ mmienu kɔntraagye a ɛhyɛɛ aseɛ wɔ ɔpɛpɔn da a ɛtɔ so nnum wɔ 2018 mu (kɔntraagye a ɛdi kan noɔ no baa n’awieeɛ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔno [Opare-Addo] na ɔwɔ akontaa mfeɛ mmiɛnsa sɛ ɔbɛyɛ Ashanti regional security liaison officer bere a akontaa a edi kan no kɔɔ so wɔ January 5th, 2018. Akontaa no a ɔde bɛdi dwuma no fii aseɛ firi January 1, 2020, na ɛbɛkɔ so kosi December 31, 2022.</s>

en: “However, his appointment was terminated on February 19, 2021, by the national security coordinator. Upon the termination of his contract, DCOP Opare-Addo was paid his entitlements as per his appointment letter. Subsequent to the termination of the appointment, the ministry appointed Col Francis Arthur (rtd) as the new Ashanti regional security liaison officer. The colonel’s appointment took effect from 1st May 2021. But he [Opare-Addo] refused to hand over to Colonel Francis Arthur. He then declined numerous invitations from the national security coordinator to explain his refusal to vacate the office.”
twi: “Na mmom, ɔman bammu ntotoeɛfoɔ tuu no adeɛ so wɔ ɔgyefoɔ da a ɛtɔ so du-nkron mu wɔ 2021 mu. Wɔtuu no adeɛ so nyinaa akyi no, na wɔtua DCOP Opare-Addo ka sɛdeɛ na ne kɔntraagye no teɛ no. Wɔtuu no adeɛ so no, wɔde ɔolonel Francis Arthur sii n’anan sɛ Asante mantam mu bammɔ adwuma ntotoeɛfoɔ. Kɛnnel dwuamdie yi hyɛɛ aseɛ firii bosome a ɛtɔ num no, ne da a ɛdi kan. Nso, Opare-Addo annyae mu amma ɔolonel Francis Arthur. ɔman bammɔ adwuma ntotoeɛfoɔ too ne nsa frɛɛ Opare-Addo mprɛ bebree sɛ ɔmmɛkyerɛ deɛ nti a ɔse ɔmfiri adeɛ so, nso wankɔ.”
mt0: <pad> Nanso, ɔde ne dwumadie no bɛyɛɛ awiee wɔ February 19, 2021, na national security coordinator no de no kɔɔ so. DCOP Opare-Addo no nsii ne dwumadie no firi Colonel Francis Arthur (rtd) no so.</s>

en: Mr Dapaah further explained “Meanwhile, his continuous stay in office obstructed the work of the new regional security liaison officer. Against this backdrop, personnel from the ministry of national security were on 11th May 2021 dispatched to the Ashanti region to ascertain the reason for DCOP Opare Addo’s refusal to vacate his office. And if it became necessary to change the locks of the door to his office. On arrival, the personnel duly introduced themselves but were met with acts of hostility from DCOP Opare-Addo, including drawing his sidearm. The personnel managed to persuade him and retrieved the sidearm.”
twi: Mr Dapaah san nso kyerɛɛ mu sɛ, “ɛsiane sɛ wannyae ne dwumadie no mu nti, na mantam no bammɔ adwuma ntotoeɛfoɔ foforɔ no a waba no ntumi nyɛ n’adwuma. Wei nti, wɔsomaa bammɔ adwumayɛfoɔ wɔ bosome a ɛtɔ so num no, ne da a ɛyɛ du-baako wɔ 2021 mu sɛ wɔnkɔ Asante mantam mu nkɔhwɛ deɛ nti a DCOP Opare-Addo sɛ ɔmfiri ne diberɛ so. Na sɛ ɛho bɛhia a, wɔmfa krado foforɔ nto ɔfese no mu. Wɔduruiɛ no, bammɔ adwumayɛfoɔ yi yii wɔn ho kyerɛɛ DCOP Opare-Addo nso annye wɔn fɛ so a ɔtwee tuo nyinaa. Wɔne no kaeɛ maa ɔde tuo maa wɔn.”
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ, "Dae no, ɔkɔɔ so ara wɔ office no nti, nnipa a ɛfiri National Security Ministry no kɔɔ Ashanti Region no kɔɔ hɔ sɛ wɔbɛhwɛ sɛ DCOP Opare-Addo yɛ adwene sɛ ɔbɛgye ne dwumadie no. Nanso, wɔn akɔ hɔ no, wɔn ho yɛɛ hu na DCOP Opare-Addo de n'arm kyerɛɛ wɔn. Nnipa no tumi twetwee n'arm no afiri DCOP Opare-Addo's nsa mu.</s>

en: He added “till date, no official complaint has been made by DCOP Opare-Addo either to his immediate boss the national security coordinator or to me as the sector minister regarding the alleged assault on him. Neither has the minister of national security received any correspondence from the police in relation to the allegations.”
twi: ɔde kaa ho bio sɛ, “Bɛsi nnɛ DCOP Opare-Addo mfa biribiara nkɔtoo ɔman bammɔ adwuma ntotoeɛfoɔ anim anaa me a meyɛ sɛkhyin soafoɔ anim sɛ obi de ne nsa aka no. Saa nso na ɔman bammɔ ntotoeɛfoɔ no nnyaa nteeɛ biara mfiri apolisifoɔ hɔ sɛ ɔde asɛm biara abɛto wɔn anim.”

en: “I will want to assure the house of our willingness to investigate the incident should any official complaint be made by DCOP Opare-Addo.”
twi: Sɛ DCOP Opare-Addo fa kwan pa so de kwaadu bɔ onipa biara a, mɛserɛ sɛ wɔbɛyɛ nhwehwɛmu afa asɛm yi ho.

en: Outgoing British High Commissioner to Ghana, Iain Walker, and Chief Executive Officer of EIB Network Nathan Kwabena Adisi also known as Bola Ray on Wednesday embarked on a ‘Waakye tour’ on the streets of Accra along with King Promise.
twi: British Haekɔmisa a ɔwɔ Ghana a n’aberɛ atwa mu, Iain Walker ne EIB Network krakye paninpaa, Nathan Kwabena Adisi a nnipa dodoɔ no ara frɛ no Bola Ray kɔɔ Waakye ho aporɔbɔ da Wukuada wɔ Nkran abɔntene so. Wɔne King Promise na ɔkɔeɛ.
mt0: <pad> British High Commissioner to Ghana, Iain Walker, and Chief Executive Officer of EIB Network Nathan Kwabena Adisi also known as Bola Ray on Wednesday embarked on a ‘Waakye tour’ on the streets of Accra along with King Promise.</s>

en: The tour dubbed ‘Taste Ghana’ spearheaded by Bola Ray was to give the High Commissioner a taste of Ghana’s popular street dishes. The Waakye tour started from a popular Waakye joint at Accra New Town and ended at one of the preferred Waakye joints in Nima.
twi: Aporɔbɔ a na wɔato ne din “Taste Ghana” a Bola Ray di anim no botaeɛ ne sɛ ɔbɛma Britain Haekɔmisa no bɛdi Ghana nnuane ahodoɔ no bi. Wɔhyɛɛ Waakye aporɔbɔ no ase wɔ baabi a wɔtɔn waakye a agye din wɔ Accra New Town na wɔkɔwiee wɔ baabi a wɔtɔn waakye ahodoɔ wɔ Nima.
mt0: <pad> Ghanafoɔ no a wɔde ‘Taste Ghana’ kyerɛɛ Ɔmanpanin no sɛ ɔbɛn Ghanafoɔ no nnuane a wɔde di dwuma.</s>

en: Police in Adeiso in the Eastern Region have intercepted four (4) pump action guns and seventy-eight live cartridges from a vehicle allegedly belonging to a sand-winning Company.
twi: Apolisifoɔ a wɔwɔ Adeiso a ɛwɔ Apueeɛ mantam mu agye atuo nnan kateregyi aduonu-nson firii kɔmpɛne a wɔtu anwea kaa mu.
mt0: <pad> Polisifoɔ a wɔwɔ Adeiso wɔ East Region no ahyɛ pump action guns ne cartridges bɛyɛ 77 afiri ɛka nnipa a wɔde kɔɔ a na ɛyɛ sand-winning Company.</s>

en: Information gathered indicates that on June 21, 2021, at about 3:00 am Adeiso Police Command gathered intelligence that there was illegal sand winning ongoing at Okaikrom community near Adeiso.
twi: Adeiso apolisifoɔ de too dwa sɛ, wɔnyaa no nteeɛ wɔ Kɔtɔnima da a ɛtɔ so aduonu baako sɛ nkorɔfoɔ bi retu anwea wɔ Okaikrom mpɔtam a ɛbɛn Adeiso (wei kɔɔ so ahomagye nnɔn mmiɛnsaɔ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkyerɛwde a wɔahunu no kyerɛ sɛ June 21, 2021, bɛyɛ anɔpa 3:00am Adeiso Police Command nyaa nsɛm a ɛfa illegal sand winning a na ɛrekɔ so wɔ Okaikrom community near Adeiso.</s>

en: Police dispatched a team to the area and met some tipper trucks and two payloaders winning sand.
twi: Apolisifoɔ kɔɔ beaeɛ hɔ na wɔkɔtoo tipa terak ahodoɔ ne peelɔdɛs mmienu sɛ wɔretu anwea.
mt0: <pad> Polisifoɔ de nnipa kɔɔ beaeɛ no na wɔhuu trucks a ɛwɔ tipper ne payloaders a wɔreyɛ sand.</s>

en: The tipper truck drivers and the payloader operators sped off on seeing the Police but the Police managed to arrest suspect Klutse Kofi who was in charge of Mitsubishi Pickup with registration number GE 7191-19.
twi: Adrɔbafoɔ a na wɔretwe tipa teraks no ne wɔn a na wɔde peelɔdɛs no reyɛ adwuma no dwaneeɛ berɛ wɔhunu sɛ apolisifoɔ reba no, na nso apolisifoɔ bɔɔ wɔn ho mmɔden kyee Klutse Kofi a na Mitsubishi kaa a ne nɔmma yɛ GE 7191-19 yɛ no dea.
mt0: <pad> Tiper truck drivers ne payloader operators kɔɔ wɔn ho akyi bere a wɔhuu Police no nanso Police no tumi kyeree suspect Klutse Kofi a Mitsubishi Pickup no sɛdeɛ ɛyɛ GE 7191-19.</s>

en: A search conducted in the Pickup led to the retrieval of four Pump Action guns with 78 live cartridges.
twi: Wɔhunu atuo nnan ne kateregyi aduoson-wɔtwe wɔ ne kaa no mu berɛ na wɔrehwehwɛ kaa no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔhwehwɛmu a wɔyɛɛ wɔ Pickup no maa wɔnyaa Pump Action nnubɔne nnan a wɔde ade ayɛ ne cartridges a ɛwɔ mu a ɛyɛ 78</s>

en: The Public Relations Officer of the Eastern Regional Police Command confirmed the arrest to Starr News.
twi: Apueeɛ mantam mu apolisifoɔ ɔmanfoɔ ntam nkitahodie krakye de too Starr news anim sɛ ɛyɛ ampa sɛ wɔakye saa nipa yi.
mt0: <pad> Eastern Regional Police Command Public Relations Officer confirmed the arrest to Starr News.</s>

en: He said the suspect told Police that the weapons belonged to Sammertide Construction and Sand Winning Company.
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ nipa wɔkyee no sɛ atuo a na ɛgu kaa no mu no yɛ Sammertide ɔonstruɔtion ne Sand Winning company no dea.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaeɛ sɛ ɔkyeree no kaa sɛ nnubɔne no yɛ Sammertide Construction and Sand Winning Company.</s>

en: He said the suspect has been detained while the four Pump Action guns retained at the Station.
twi: ɔkyerɛ sɛ wɔde saa nipa ne atuo a na ɛwɔ kaa no mu akɔ apolisifoɔ akakye.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ɔhyɛɛ no kwaadu no na wɔde Pump Action nnubɔne nnan a wɔde kɔɔ apolisifoɔ no so no bɛgyinaa wɔn so.</s>

en: This is happening on the back of an attack on the mining site by some armed men.
twi: Wei siiɛ berɛ na wɔrekye nkorɔfoɔ a etuo wɔ wɔn ho wɔ beaeɛ a na wɔretu anwea no.
mt0: <pad> Ɛkɔɔ so wɔ nnipa a wɔde nnuru bɛyɛɛ sɛdeɛ wɔbɛkyeree mmeaeɛ a wɔrekɔkyeree no mu.</s>

en: On June 15, 2021, at about 2:00 pm, the first complainant Osae Kwame was returning from his farm to Adeiso town to buy food for his farm labourers but met the accused persons who were in a convoy of three pick-up vehicles and a Jeep vehicle with registration number GS 9835-19, stopped by him, handcuffed and abducted him into one of the Pick-Up vehicles and drove him to Tank Akuraa a farming community near Adeiso.
twi: Awia nnɔn mmienu mu, Kɔtɔnima da a ɛtɔ so du-num a wɔ 2021 mu na akorɔfoɔ a na wɔte piɔk-up mmiɛnsa mu ne ɛeep kaa mu a na ne nɔmma yɛ GS 9835-19 kyee Osae Kwame (onipa ɔdii kan kɔbɔɔ amanneɛɔ berɛ na ɔfiri n’afuo reba Adeiso abɛtɔ aduane akɔma n’adwumayɛfoɔ wɔ n’afuom. Wɔde aban kawa guu no nsa, kyee no hyɛɛ piɔk-up no baako mu de no kɔɔ Tank Akuraa a, korɔ baako a ɛbɛn Adeiso.
mt0: <pad> Na ɛbɛyɛ June 15, 2021, no mu a ɔrekɔ sɛ ɔbɛgye aduane afiri ne nsuo mu a, ɔdii kan kyerɛɛ sɛ ɔbɛkɔ Adeiso kuro akɔ gye aduane ma ne nsuo mu adwumakuw no na wɔde Jeep a ɛwɔ registration number GS 9835-19 kɔɔ ne ho, bɛtɔɔ no, bɛhyɛɛ no, bɛkɔɔ ne ho kɔɔ Tank Akuraa a ɛwɔ Adeiso kuro a ɛbɛn Adeiso.</s>

en: Police upon receipt of distress calls about the incident rushed to the village and rescued him but the accused persons sped off from the scene and invaded the Summertide Company sand-winning site at Obeng Yaw village also near Adeiso amidst sporadic firing of gunshots.
twi: Apolisifoɔ tee saa asɛm yi, wɔde ammirika kɔɔ akuraa no ase kɔgyee no, na mmom wɔn a wɔkyee no no dwaneeɛ kɔɔ beaeɛ a Summertide companytu anwea wɔ Obeng Yaw akuraase a ɛbɛn Adeiso a na wɔretoto atuo.
mt0: <pad> Polisifoɔ a wɔde distress calls abe sɛ ɛkɔɔ nkuro no na wɔhyɛɛ no nsow, nanso nnipa a wɔkyeree no fiii hɔ na wɔkɔɔ Summertide Company sand-winning site wɔ Obeng Yaw nkuro no nso bɛyɛ Adeiso a ɛwɔ Adeiso nkyɛn.</s>

en: The second complainant Alhassan Zakari was shot on the left leg during the indiscriminate firing of gunshots.
twi: Onipa a ɛtɔ so mmienu a ɔkɔ yii apolisifoɔ asotire, Alhassan Zakari deɛ, berɛ a na wɔretoto tuo basaabasaa no, etuo kaa no.
mt0: <pad> Alhassan Zakari a ɔkaeɛ no sɛ ɔyɛɛ adeɛ no mu wɔ ne nan akyi bere a wɔde nneɛma bɛtow no.</s>

en: They violently arrested five(5) persons at the site, whisked them into their vehicles, and drove away to an unknown location.
twi: Wɔde aniɛden kyee nnipa baanum wɔ saa beaeɛ hɔ a, wɔsoaa wɔn nyinaa guu kaa mu de wɔn kɔɔ baabi a na wɔnnim hɔ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman no kyeree nnipa nnum wɔ beae hɔ, de wɔn kɔɔ wɔn kaa mu, na wɔde wɔn kɔɔ beae a wɔnim.</s>

en: The owner of the site alleged he later detected that the accused persons stole Ghc96,000 at the site during the gun violence.
twi: Deɛ na baabi a wɔretu anwea wɔ no no de too dwa sɛ, akyire yi na ɔhunuu sɛ wɔfaa ne GH¢96,000 berɛ na wɔretoto tuo no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanfoɔ no kaeɛ sɛ ɔde gyinabea no ho nsuo bɛyɛ Ghc96,000 kɔɔ wɔn so bere a ɔkyeree nsuo no mu no.</s>

en: The five persons arrested by the accused persons were later rescued by Kyebi Police after the wireless message was activated by police.
twi: Kyebi apolisifoɔ kɔgyee saa nnipa baanum a saa nkorɔfoɔ yi kyee wɔn no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no kyeree nnipa nnan a wɔde wɔn nsa aka no na Kyebi Police no bɛgyee wɔn akyi bere a ɛkɔɔ so sɛ ɛyɛ wireless message a Kyebi Police no de kɔɔ so.</s>

en: At about 4:20 pm, the accused persons were arrested by the Adeiso Police.
twi: Anwummerɛ nnɔnnan mpaemu na Adeiso apolisifoɔ kɔkyee saa nkorɔfoɔ yi.
mt0: <pad> Ɛbɔɔ bɛyɛ anwummere 4:20 pm, Adeiso Police no kyeree nnipa a wɔaka no.</s>

en: The victims -Alhassan Zakaria and Bright Apama who sustained gunshot wounds on their legs were receiving treatment at the Eastern Regional Hospital in Koforidua.
twi: Wɔde Alhassan Zakaria ne Bright Apama a etuo kaa wɔn nan no kɔɔ Apueeɛ mantam ayaresabea wɔ Koforidua.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanfoɔ no - Alhassan Zakaria ne Bright Apama a wɔpiraeɛ wɔ wɔn nan so no na wɔrehwɛ wɔn wɔ Eastern Regional Hospital wɔ Koforidua.</s>

en: Meanwhile, the Eastern Regional CID has taken over the case.
twi: Seisei deɛ, Apueeɛ mantam CID na asɔ saa asɛm yi mu.
mt0: <pad> Eastern Regional CID no deɛ ɔyɛɛ saa nhyehyɛe yi ase.</s>

en: Accused persons granted Bail
twi: Wɔama wɔn a wɔkyee wɔn no beele.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkyeree nnipa a wɔaka no sɛ wɔbɛka sɛ wɔnim.</s>

en: The Koforidua Circuit Court admitted the five(5) accused persons including Akyem Abuakwa chief who claim to be a National Security Operative to bail in the sum of 200,000 cedis with 2 sureties.
twi: Koforidua Sɛɛkut kɔɔto ama saa nnipa baanum a wɔkyee wɔn a na Akyem Abuakwa hene a na ɔkyerɛ sɛ ɔyɛ ɔman bammɔ adwumayɛni ka ho no GH¢200,000 beeli a agyinamudifoɔ mmienu nsa nhyɛ aseɛ.
mt0: <pad> Koforidua Circuit Court no de nnipa nnum a wɔkyeree wɔn no kɔɔ afiase 200,000 cedis na wɔde ɛho bɛka sɛ ɔyɛ National Security Operative no.</s>

en: The accused persons are Nana Barfuor Sarpong, Nana Barima Twum Tarbiade II, both sub-chiefs in Akyem Abuakwa.
twi: Wɔn a wɔde kwaadu bɔɔ wɔn ne Nana Barfuor Sarpong, Nana Barima Twum Tarbiade II a na wɔn nyinaa yɛ ahemfo wɔ Akyem Abuakwa.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanfoɔ a wɔkyeree no ne Nana Barfuor Sarpong, Nana Barima Twum Tarbiade II, a wɔyɛ sub-chiefs wɔ Akyem Abuakwa.</s>

en: The rest are Jonathan Martey ,Eric Yaw Obeng ,Victor Ahenkora Koranteng ,and others at large .
twi: Wɔn a wɔka ho ne ɛonathan Martey, Eric Yaw Boateng, Viɔtor Ahenkora Koranteng ne wɔn a wɔkeka ho.
mt0: <pad> Jonathan Martey, Eric Yaw Obeng, Victor Ahenkora Koranteng, and others at large.</s>

en: They were arraigned before the court on Friday, June 19, 2021, on seven charges which are; conspiracy to commit a crime with kidnapping, Kidnapping, causing unlawful harm, stealing, conspiracy to commit robbery, robbery, possession of firearm and ammunition
twi: Wɔde wɔn bɛgyinaa kɔɔto anim wɔ Kɔtɔnima da a ɛtɔ so du-nkron mu wɔ 2021 mu a wɔde kwaadu ahodoɔ nson bɔɔ wɔn. Wei ne: nhyehyɛeɛ sɛ wɔbɛkye obi akɔsie, wɔkyee obi kɔsieeɛ, wɔadi nkorɔfoɔ dɛm, korɔnobɔ, nhyehyɛeɛ sɛ wɔbɛbɔ korɔno ne sɛ etuo hyehyɛ wɔn ho.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no de wɔn kɔɔ afiase wɔ Friday, June 19, 2021, wɔ akwantuo mu ɛho nsɛm a ɛyɛ; conspiracy to commit a crime with kidnapping, Kidnapping, causing unlawful harm, stealing, conspiracy to commit robbery, robbery, possession of firearm and ammunition.</s>

en: The case has been adjourned to 19th July 2021.
twi: Watu asɛm no de akɔhyɛ Kitawonsa da a ɛtɔ so du-nkron wɔ 2021 mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkwan no ayɛ wɔn sɛ wɔbɛkɔ July 19, 2021</s>

en: The Prosecuting Officer Cyril Boateng Keteku, Assistant State Attorney explained to the court that, the first complainant in the case, Osae Kwame, 59, is a farmer while the second complainant Alhassan Zakari, 39, is also a farmer.
twi: Kwaadubɔfoɔ ɔfesa Cyril Boateng Keteku a ɔyɛ aban lɔya abadiakyiri de too kɔɔto no anim sɛ, Osae Kwame (wadi mfeɛ aduonum nkronɔ ne Alhassan Zakari (wadi mfeɛ aduasa nkronɔ a nkorɔfoɔ yi teetee wɔn no nyinaa yɛ akuafoɔ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin Cyril Boateng Keteku, Assistant State Attorney kyerɛɛ ɔmanpanin no sɛ, ɔmanpanin a ɔdi kan wɔ saa nsɛm no mu ne Alhassan Zakari, 39, a ɔyɛ ɔmanpanin.</s>

en: The third complainant Samuel Astu Forson is Chief of Adeiso also Executive Officer of Summertide sand winning Company.
twi: Deɛ ɛtɔ so mmiɛnsa yɛ Samuel Astu Forson a ɔyɛ Adeisohene a ɔsan nso yɛ krakye paninpaa wɔ Summertide Sand Winning ɔompany.
mt0: <pad> Samuel Astu Forson yɛ Adeiso Chief na ɔyɛ Executive Officer of Summertide Sand Winning Company.</s>

en: He said the accused persons are Nana Baffuor Sarpong who claimed to be National Security Personnel attached to Forestry Commission as training Coordinator and timber monitoring officer.
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ, deɛ wɔde kwaadu abɔ no, Nana Baffuor Sarpong a ɔse ɔyɛ ɔman bammɔ adwumayɛni ɛnne Fɔlɛetiri kɔmisa sɛ nkyerɛkyerɛ ntotoeɛfoɔ ne obi a ɔhwɛ timba soɔ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ nnipa a wɔabɔ wɔn kwaadu no ne Nana Baffuor Sarpong a ɔkyerɛ sɛ ɔyɛ National Security Personnel attached to Forestry Commission as training Coordinator ne timber monitoring officer.</s>

en: The second accused person Nana Barima Twum Tabirade claimed to be the boundary Chief of all Akyem lands. The third accused person Jonathan Martey is a driver to Nana Barfuor, the fourth accused person Eric Yaw Obeng claimed to be an aide to the Nana Barfuor, while the fifth accused person Victor Ahenkora Koranteng claimed to be Immigration Officer.
twi: Deɛ ɔtɔ so mmienu ne Nana Barima Twum Tabirade a ɔyɛ ɔhene a ɔhwɛ Akyem asase so. Deɛ ɔtɔ so mmiɛnsa ne ɛonathan Martey a ɔyɛ Nana Barfuor drɔba. Deɛ ɔtɔ so nan ne Eric Yaw Obeng a na ɔyɛ Nana Barfuor boafoɔ ɛnna deɛ ɔtɔ num ne Viɔtor Ahenkora Koranteng a ɔyɛ emigerɛhyin ɔfesa.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman no mu nnipa a wɔkyeree wɔn no, Nana Barima Twum Tabirade yɛ Akyem Boundary Chief of all Akyem lands. The third accused person Jonathan Martey is a driver to Nana Barfuor, the fourth accused person Eric Yaw Obeng yɛ Nana Barfuor's aide, and the fifth accused person Victor Ahenkora Koranteng yɛ Immigration Officer.</s>

en: The other accused persons are at large
twi: Wɔn a wɔaka no adwane.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanfoɔ a wɔde nsɛm no kyerɛɛ no no yɛ nnipa a wɔwɔ hɔ.</s>

en: The Government has moved to avert attacks from Burkinabe bandits in Ghana as it announces the construction of permanent barracks in Bawku to enhance security in that part of the country
twi: Aban no de nhyehyɛeɛ agu akwan mu sɛ ɔbɛsi Burkinafoɔ a wɔreteetee Ghanafoɔ wɔ Bawku. Wama wɔreyɛ baraks wɔ Bawku sɛdeɛ ahobammɔ bɛtu mpɔn wɔ Bawku.
mt0: <pad> Ghana aban no aseɛ abɛyɛ sɛ ɛbɛtɔ nnipa a wɔfiri Burkinabe kɔkɔbɔ mu no kwaadu a ɛbɛba Ghana bere a ɛkyerɛ sɛ ɛbɛyɛ permanent barracks wɔ Bawku sɛdeɛ ɛbɛboa ama ɛho hia akɔ so wɔ saa beaeɛ no mu.</s>

en: The announcement made by President Akufo-Addo comes just a week after security agencies were put on high alert to fore-planned attacks by bandits from Burkina Faso.
twi: ɔmampanin Akufo-Addo de saa nsɛm yi too dwa aberɛ a bammɔ kuo ahodoɔ adwene kɔɔ akorɔmfoɔ a wɔfiri Burkina adwumadie a wɔredi no so.
mt0: <pad> President Akufo-Addo ayɛ saa nsɛm yi bɛyɛ nnawɔtwe bere a wɔde ɔman no kɔɔ so sɛ anka bandits bɛba Ghana.</s>

en: He was speaking at a meeting with the Bawku Naba to end his tour of the Upper-East region.
twi: ɔde saa nsɛm yi too dwa berɛ ɔhia Bawku Naba berɛ ɔde n’aporɔbɔ wɔ Atifi Apueeɛ mantam mu reba awieeɛ no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa no wɔ nnipaku naba a wɔwɔ Upper East no mu de bɛwiee ne nanteɛ no.</s>

en: “The proximity of your region to Burkina Faso makes it an obvious potential target for these murderers and criminals who want to destabilize and terrorize our lives in Ghana.”
twi: Sɛdeɛ mantam yi bɛn Burkina Faso no nti na saa atiretrafoɔ yi a wɔpɛ sɛ wɔde ɔhaw ne amanneɛ ba Ghana mu yi reteetee mo.
mt0: <pad> “The proximity of your region to Burkina Faso makes it an obvious potential target for these murderers and criminals who want to destabilize and terrorize our lives in Ghana.”</s>

en: He went on”Bawku Naba, you are aware of the measures that the government is taking to strengthen the security agencies here and protect us from terrorist attacks emanating from Burkina Faso.
twi: ɔtoaa so sɛ, “Bawku Naba, wonim nhyehyɛeɛ a aban no de agu akwan mu sɛdeɛ ɛbɛboa ama bammɔ ho nsɛm atu mpɔn na asi saa atiretrafoɔ a wɔfiri Burkina Faso dwumadie yi ano.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkɔɔ so sɛ, "Bawku Naba, wo nim nsɛm a aban no reyɛ de bɛhyɛ apolisifoɔ no ho ban wɔ hɔ na ama yɛn ho ate asraafoɔ a wɔfiri Burkina Faso bɛkae yɛn.</s>

en: “And I’m happy to inform you that a permanent baracks is going to be established here in this area to be able to address the issue of terrorism.”
twi: “ɛyɛ me ani gye sɛ mede bɛto mo anim sɛ wɔrebɛsi asraafoɔ atenaeɛ wɔ saa mpɔtam mu yi mu na wɔaboa asi atiretrasɛm a ɛrekɔ so no ano.”
mt0: <pad> “Na me ani gye ho sɛ mɛka sɛ wɔbɛyɛ permanent barracks wɔ saa beae yi mu sɛ yɛbɛtumi akɔ so atwe terrorism ɔhaw no.”</s>

en: Meanwhile, the Bawku Naba, who is also President of the Kusaug Traditional Council, Asigiri Abugrago Azoka II, said the Chiefs and People of the Kusaug Traditional Area, and, indeed, all Ghanaians appreciate the policies of the President of the Republic, Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo.
twi: Asigiri Abugrago Azoka II a ɔyɛ Bawku Naba na ɔsan nso yɛ ɔtitenani ma Kusaug ahemfo ano no de too dwa sɛ, ahemfo ne nnipa a wɔwɔ Kusaug mpɔtam mu no ne Ghanafoɔ nyinaa ani sɔ nhyehyɛeɛ a Ghana mampanin, Nana Addo Dankwah Akufo-Addo de agu akwan mu no ho.
mt0: <pad> Nanso, Ɔmanpanin Asigiri Abugrago Azoka II, a ɔyɛ Kusaug Traditional Council President, kae sɛ Ghanafoɔ ne nnipa a wɔwɔ Kusaug Traditional Area no anigye Ghanafoɔ aban no nsɛm a ɔde di dwuma.</s>

en: Congratulating President Akufo-Addo on his electoral victory, “which has put the destiny of Ghana firmly in your hands for the next four (4) years”, the Bawku Naba told the President that “you have worked hard to earn that enviable position. I wish you God’s continued blessing in wisdom as well as good health to execute your policies.”
twi: ɔrebɔ ɔmampanin Akufo-Addo aba wɔ nkonimdie a ɔdii no wɔ abatoɔ no mu no a ɔman no nkrabea ahyɛ ne nsam mfeɛ nan a ɛdi yɛn anim no, Bawku Naba de too ɔmampanin anim sɛ, “Woayɛ adwumaden nti na woanya saa diberɛ yi. Mebɔ mpaeɛ sɛ Nyame bɛdom wo nyansa ne ahoɔden ama woatumi de wo nhyehyɛeɛ nyinaa a wode agu akwan mu no bɛwie pɛyɛ.
