en: 19-year-old Thomas Amoani, a graduate of the Adeiso Presbyterian Senior High School who was offered a full scholarship by the Ghana Scholarships Secretariat has expressed his appreciation to the government of President Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo Addo.
twi: Thomas Amoani a wadi mfeɛ du-nkron a ɔwiee sukuu wɔ Adeiso Presbyterian Senior High School a ɔnyaa sokɔlahyip afiri Ghana Sɔholarships Secretariat hɔ no ada aban a ɔmampanin Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo Addo ase.
mt0: <pad> Thomas Amoani, 19, a ɔdii Adeiso Presbyterian Senior High School no mu a wɔde scholarship maeɛ no, kyerɛɛ ne nkuran sɛ Ghana Scholarships Secretariat no ama no sika bɛyɛ Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛwɔ Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛwɔ Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛwɔ Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛwɔ Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛwɔ Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghanafoɔ sika a ɛboro Ghana

en: Thomas Amoani, who had eight A‘s in last year’s West Africa Secondary School Certificate Examination was immediately offered a scholarship to study at the prestigious Brunel University in London after a directive to the Registrar of the Secretariat, Mr Kingsley Agyemang.
twi: Krakyepanin a ɔwɔ asoeɛ hɔ, Owura Kingsley Agyemang de ato dwa sɛ, wɔama Thomas Amoani a ɔnyaa A nko ara nwɔtwe wɔ West Africa Seɔondary School Certificate Examination afe a ɛtwaa mu no sokɔlahyip sɛ ɔrekɔsua adeɛ wɔ suapɔn kɛseɛ Brunel University a ɛwɔ London mu.
mt0: <pad> Thomas Amoani, a ɔwɔ A's nnum wɔ West Africa Secondary School Certificate Examination no mu afei, na wɔde scholarship maa no kɔsua wɔ Brunel University wɔ London.</s>

en: The 19-year-old boy, from Asuaba, near Adeiso and from a very poor background, will be studying Economics and Business Finance for his bachelor’s degree.
twi: Aberanteɛ a wadi mfeɛ du-nkron a ɔfiri Asuaba a ɛbɛn Adeiso na sika nni fie yi bɛsua Economics ne Business Finanɔe wɔ suapɔn no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔbaa a wadi mfe 19, ɔfiri Asuaba, bɛyɛ Adeiso, na ɔfiri nnipa a wɔwɔ ɔhaw paa mu no, bɛsua Economics ne Business Finance sɛ ɔbɛnya degree.</s>

en: The story of the former student of the Adeiso SHS made headlines after he was interviewed by a news portal. Sharing his story, Thomas Amoani recounted how he used to trek for about 12 kilometres to school.
twi: N’awerɛhosɛm yi hyetaa ɔman no mu nyinaa berɛ osuani yi ne nsɛntwerɛfoɔ twetwee nkɔmmɔ. ɔreka n’akosɛm, Thomas Amoani de too dwa sɛ na ɛtɔ mmerɛ bi a ɔtwa kwansini kilomita du-mmienu ansa ne waduru ne sukuu mu.
mt0: <pad> Thomas Amoani a na ɔyɛ Adeiso SHS sukuufo no kaa ne ho wɔ nsɛm a ɛkɔɔ so bere a nsɛm a ɛkɔɔ so no bɛyɛɛ headlines bere a nsɛm a ɛkɔɔ so no bɛyɛɛ headlines.</s>

en: This caught the attention of His Excellency President Akufo-Addo who immediately asked that he be offered a full scholarship.
twi: ɔmampanin Akufo-Addo tee saa asɛm yi na ɔhyɛɛ sɛ wɔmma no sokɔlahyip.
mt0: <pad> Ɛno kɔɔ so sɛdeɛ Ɔmanpanin Akufo-Addo no ani gyee no na ɔkaa sɛ wɔbɛma no scholarship a ɛyɛ sika a ɛboro sika a ɛwɔ n'adwene mu.</s>

en: During a short media engagement held for him prior to his departure at the Scholarship Secretariat, the Registrar said the honour done Thomas by the President will go a long way to motivate others to also strive hard academically irrespective of their background.
twi: ɔrefiri asoeɛ hɔ no, krakyepanin a ɔwɔ asoeɛ hɔ de too nsɛntwerɛfoɔ anim sɛ, adeɛ ɔmampanin ayɛ ama Thomas no bɛhyɛ wɔn a wɔaka no nkuran ama wɔasua adeɛ yie ɛmfa ho ne fie a wɔfiri mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no ama Thomas no sɛdeɛ ɔbɛyɛ adwuma wɔ sukuu mu no, Registrar no kaeɛ sɛ nnipa a wɔwɔ sukuu mu no bɛbɔ mmɔden sɛ wɔbɛyɛ adwuma wɔ sukuu mu ɛno nanso ɛbɛboa nnipa a wɔwɔ sukuu mu no sɛ wɔbɛyɛ adwuma wɔ sukuu mu ɛno nanso ɛbɛboa nnipa a wɔwɔ sukuu mu no sɛ wɔbɛyɛ adwuma wɔ sukuu mu no.</s>

en: “I foresee a lot of Thomases coming up and I can assure them that the Scholarships Secretariat will be there to offer them the needed support. Thomas’ story should be a motivation to others like him. And I must commend President Akufo-Addo for his swift intervention,” Mr. Agyemang said.
twi: Owura Agyemang de too dwa sɛ, “mehunu sɛ nnipa bebree a wɔte Thomas wɔ hɔ na merehyɛ wɔn bɔ sɛ sokɔlahyip asoeɛ wɔ hɔ sɛ wɔbɛyɛ wɔn mmoa. ɛwɔ Thomas asɛm yi hyɛ wɔn a wɔte no no nkuran. Mɛbɔ ɔmampanin Akufo-Addo aba so wɔ deɛ wayɛ yi ho.”
mt0: <pad> “Mehwɛ kwan sɛ Thomases bebree bɛba na me betumi aka wɔn sɛ Scholarships Secretariat no bɛwɔ hɔ sɛ ɛbɛma wɔn nkwadaa a ɛho hia. Thomas’ story bɛyɛ adeɛ a ɛbɛboa afoforɔ sɛ ɛte saa. Na me nso ɛsɛ sɛ m'anigyedeɛ kɔ so kyerɛ Ɔmanpanin Akufo-Addo sɛ ɔde ne ho adi dwuma ntɛm.</s>

en: Arriving at the university campus, Thomas Amoani, who could not hide his joy says he is ready to raise the flag of Ghana high and will not let the country down.
twi: ɔduruu suapɔn mu hɔ no, Thomas Amoani a n’ani agye de too dwa sɛ ɔbɛhyɛ ne man Ghana animuonyam na ɔmma Ghana nsa nsi fam da.
mt0: <pad> Thomas Amoani, a ɔyɛɛ n'adwene no sɛ ɔbɛgyina Ghana flag no so na ɔbɛma Ghana akɔ anim.</s>

en: “I never imagined I will be given such an opportunity by Mr. President through the hardworking Registrar. I am very grateful for the confidence reposed in me. I will not fail my country Ghana,” he said.
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ, “Manna anwene da sɛ ɔmampanin bɛfa krakyepanin no so ama ma akwannya a ɛte sei da. Meda wɔn ase wɔ gyidie a wɔanya wɔ me mu. Memma me man Ghana anim ngu ase.”
mt0: <pad> “Me nsusueɛ sɛ mɛnya saa ɔkwan yi afiri Mr. President no mu ɛfiri Registrar no so. Me ho dwo paa sɛ wɔde me bɛgyina sɛ Ghanafoɔ bɛyɛ me adwuma. Mɛnkɔmmɔ Ghanafoɔ a, Ghana,” ɔkaa.</s>

en: Brunel University London is a public research university located in the Uxbridge area of London, England. Founded in 1966 and named after the Victorian engineer Isambard Kingdom Brunel, it is ranked as the 93rd best university worldwide in the field of engineering and technology, 32nd among European institutions and 11th among British institutions according to THES world rankings.
twi: Brunel University London yɛ suapɔn bi a ɛwɔ Uxbridge mpɔtam mu a ɛwɔ London, England. Wɔtee saa suapɔn yi wɔ 2966 mu na wɔde saa suapɔn yi too Isambard Kingdom Brunel. Wiase mu nyinaa no sɛ ɛba engyiniɛ ne tɛknɔlɔgyi mu a, saa suapɔn yi tɔ so aduonkron mmiɛnsa, ɛnna ɛtɔ so aduasa mmienu wɔ Europe. THES nhwehwɛmu a wɔde baeɛ kyerɛ sɛ, saa suapɔn yi tɔ so du-baako sɛ ɛba suapɔn a ɛwɔ Britain man mu.
mt0: <pad> Brunel University London yɛ ɔmanfo a wɔn ho yɛ adwuma ɛwɔ Uxbridge, London, England. Wɔtee no 1966 na wɔtoo ne din Isambard Kingdom Brunel, ɛyɛ 93rd best university worldwide wɔ engineering ne technology mu, 32nd among European institutions and 11th among British institutions according to THES world rankings.</s>

en: There is no problem with the Chief Justice, Justice Kwasi Anin Yeboah filing a disciplinary complaint against legal practitioner and Member of Parliament for Bolgatanga East, Dr Dominic Akuritinga Ayine at the General Legal Council (GLC).
twi: Mfomsoɔ biara nni ho sɛ ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa, ɔtemmuafoɔ Kwasi Anin Yeboah de kwaadu bɛbɔ Dr. Dominic Akuritinga Ayine a ɔyɛ lɔya na ɔsan nso yɛ Bolgatanga East mmarahyɛbɛdwani wɔ General Legal Council (GLC)
mt0: <pad> Ɔman panin no, Justice Kwasi Anin Yeboah de ɔkwan biara nni hɔ sɛ ɔbɛkyerɛ a wɔde kɔmputa a ɛfa ɔyɛ adwumayɛfoɔ ne Mprenpren a ɔfiri Bolgatanga East, Dr Dominic Akuritinga Ayine kɔ General Legal Council (GLC).</s>

en: According to private legal practitioner and former Member of Parliament for Zebilla, Mr John Ndebugre, the arguments being made by the National Democratic Congress (NDC) and other people against the complaint are issues, which should be dealt with when Dr Ayine appears before the Disciplinary Committee of the General Legal Council (GLC).
twi: Zebilla mmarahyɛbɛdwani dadaa, lɔya John Ndebugre kyerɛ sɛ nsɛm a National Democratic Congress (NDCɔ ne wɔn a wɔkeka ho reka ɛfa saa kwaadu bɔ yi ho no, ɛwɔ sɛ Dr Ayine ba Genral Legal Council (GLɔɔ no asotwee kɔmitee no anim na wɔka ho asɛm.
mt0: <pad> According to private legal practitioner and former Member of Parliament for Zebilla, Mr John Ndebugre, the arguments being made by the National Democratic Congress (NDC) and other people against the complaint are issues, which should be dealt with when Dr Ayine appears before the Disciplinary Committee of the General Legal Council (GLC).</s>

en: "I think he [Chief Justice] was the proper person to initiate a complaint because the statement that Dr Ayine made which resulted in this complaint was that, in summary, his confidence in the independence of the judiciary has been shaken somehow by the manner in which the presidential election petition was handled or determined."
twi: “Megye di sɛ na ɔtemmuafo panin paa ne nnipa a ɛwɔ sɛ ɔhyɛ kwaadu yi ase ɛfiri sɛ asɛm a Dr Ayine de too dwa maa kwaadubɔ yi baeɛ no mmuabɔ nyinaa ne sɛ, ɛnam sɛdeɛ ɔmampanin abatoɔ no kɔɔ so nti, ɔnni awerɛhyɛmu wɔ aban mmara adwuma mu.”
mt0: <pad> 'I think he [Chief Justice] was the proper person to initiate a complaint because the statement that Dr Ayine made which resulted in this complaint was that, in summary, his confidence in the independence of the judiciary has been shaken somehow by the manner in which the presidential election petition was handled or determined.</s>

en: The Chief Justice has reported lawyer Dr Dominic Akuritinga Ayine to the Disciplinary Committee of the GLC for statements he allegedly made during a panel discussion on Presidential Election Petitions and their impact on Africa's Democracy.
twi: ɛnam nsɛm a Dr Dominic Akuritinga Ayine kaeɛ berɛ a na wɔretwetwe nkɔmmɔ fa Presidential election Petition ne ɛso nsunsuansoɔ a anya wɔ Abibiman kabimamenkabi amammuo so, ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa de Dr Dominic Akuritinga Ayine akɔ GLɔ Asotee Kɔmitee anim.
mt0: <pad> Ɔsahene no de Dr Dominic Akuritinga Ayine kɔɔ Disciplinary Committee of the GLC esiane sɛ ɔkaeɛ a ɔde kaeɛ wɔ ahinanan nsɛm ho nsɛm a ɛfa Presidential Election Petitions ne sɛnea ɛbɛyɛ sɛ ɛbɛkyerɛ Africa's Democracy.</s>

en: Dr. Ayine has been accused of questioning the independence of the Judiciary due to the manner the Supreme Court adjudicated the 2020 presidential election petition.
twi: Wɔde kwaadu abɔ Dr. Ayine ɛnam kwan a ɔfaa so twee aban mmara adwumakuo no anim, ne sɛn nti ne sɛ kɔɔto peemu a ɛwɔ ɔman no mu si dii 2020 ɔmampanin abatoɔ pɛtihyin no si faeɛ.
mt0: <pad> Dr. Ayine a wɔde no kyerɛ no sɛ ɔyɛ nnipa a ɔwɔ tumi a ɔbɛdi dwuma no ho nhyehyɛe nti ɛho hia sɛ Supreme Court no bɛdi 2020 presidential election petition no ho nhyehyɛe no mu.</s>

en: The petition says Dr. Ayine’s basis for his assertion during the discussion is the Supreme Court's failure to apply the rules of procedure as well as the consistent and continuous dismissal of the petitioner's applications or reliefs.
twi: Pɛtihyin no kyerɛ sɛ, Dr. Ayine nnyinasoɔ a ɔde kaa n’asɛm no berɛ nkɔmmɔdie no rekɔ no ne sɛ kɔɔto peemu amfa mmara ɛda asennie nhyehyɛeɛ anni dwuma na afei nso na wɔbɔ pɛtihyina no relɛɛfs to gu.
mt0: <pad> petition no ka Dr. Ayine’s basis for his assertion during the discussion is the Supreme Court’s failure to apply the rules of procedure as well as the consistent and continuous dismissal of the petitioner’s applications or reliefs.</s>

en: “These comments are made against the backdrop of the Supreme Court discharging Dr. Ayine on a charge of contempt for similar comments made against members of the Supreme Court during the Election Petition hearing. Dr. Ayine apologized profusely when he appeared before the Court on the Contempt charge and admitted to having made comments which were unbecoming of a Lawyer of his standing and a former Deputy Attorney-General."
twi: “Dr Ayine kaa nsɛm bi sei faa kɔɔto peemu no ho mmerɛ bi atwa mu ɛfa abatoɔ pɛtihyin no ho maa kɔɔto peemu de kɔntɛmɛt kwaadu bɔɔ no. Dr. Ayine paa kɔɔto peemu no akyɛw berɛ a wɔde no kɔgyinaa kɔɔto peemu no anim ɛnam kɔntɛmɛt kwaadu a wɔde bɔɔ no no. Na ɔkyerɛɛ sɛ, sɛ ɔyɛ lɔyani na ɔsan nso yɛ aban lɔya panin abadiakyiri dadaa deɛ, wankasa yie.”
mt0: <pad> 'Nsɛm yi wɔ Supreme Court discharging Dr. Ayine on a charge of contempt for similar comments made against members of the Supreme Court during the Election Petition hearing. Dr. Ayine apologized profusely when he appeared before the Court on the Contempt charge and admitted to having made comments which were unbecoming of a Lawyer of his standing and a former Deputy Attorney-General.</s>

en: Dr. Ayine, in his eleven-paged response to the CJ's complaint, is insisting that his comments did not attack the reputation of the justices who sat on the election petition case.
twi: Dr. Ayine anoyie a ɔde maa atemmuafoɔ mpaninfoɔ a wɔdii abatoɔ pɛtihyin asɛm no ne sɛ, n’asɛm a ɔde too dwa no ammu wɔn animtia.
mt0: <pad> Dr. Ayine, wɔ ne nwoma ɛtɔ so du-nnum a ɔde kyerɛɛ CJ's complaint no, yɛ sɛ ɔkae sɛ ne nsɛm no anka ɛbɛma tumi a ɛwɔ Justices a wɔdii nsɛm no ho adi.</s>

en: He insists that his comments were in good faith.
twi: ɔsii so dua sɛ, wanka asɛm no wɔ kwan bɔne so.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkyerɛ sɛ ne nsɛm no yɛ anika.</s>

en: “As I have stated in this response, as a lawyer, I have a special responsibility to engage in criticism of the work of the judiciary. By reason of my training and experience, I am better placed than most of my fellow citizens to point out deficiencies in judgments and in the performance by the judiciary of its core constitutional mandate.”
twi: “Sɛdeɛ mede too dwa wɔ me mmuaeɛ mu no, ɛyɛ m’asɛdeɛ sɛ mɛbɔ aban mmara adwumakuo dwumadie no akyi. ɛnam nteteeɛ a mafa mu ne suahunu a mewɔ nti, mɛtumi akyerɛ m’adwene afa nnoɔma a ɛnkɔ yie wɔ aban mmara adwumakuo no dwumadie ho asene Ghanafoɔ no fa bi.”
mt0: <pad> Asɛm a ɔkae no wɔ saa atwerɛdeɛ yi mu no, sɛ ɔyɛ ɔfese a ɔyɛ ɔkwantuni, me ho hia paa sɛ mɛkyerɛ nsunsuansoɔ a ɛwɔ ɔkwantuni dwumadie ho. Esiane me nhomasua ne me nimdeɛ nti, me ho hia paa sɛ mɛkyerɛ nsunsuansoɔ a ɛwɔ ɔkwantuni dwumadie ho ne sɛ ɔkwantuni dwumadie no bɛyɛ ɔkwantuni dwumadie no adeɛ a ɛwɔ ɔkwantuni dwumadie no mu.</s>

en: He further posited that his comments were within the confines of fair and temperate speech.
twi: ɔsan nso de kaa ho sɛ, ne nsɛm a ɔkaeɛ no kwan so ara no no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ne nsɛm no kɔɔ so wɔ fair ne temperate speech.</s>

en: The main opposition political party, the National Democratic Congress (NDC) at a press conference in Accra on Monday asked the Chief Justice to withdraw his disciplinary complaint against Dr Ayine.
twi: Dwoada a amanyɔkuo kɛseɛ a wɔnni aban mu, National Democratic Congress (NDCɔ ne nsɛntwerɛkyerɛ hyiaa wɔ Accra no, wɔde too ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa n’anim sɛ ɔtwe kwaadu a ɔde abɔ Dr. Ayine no nsan.
mt0: <pad> National Democratic Congress (NDC) at a press conference in Accra on Monday asked the Chief Justice to withdraw his disciplinary complaint against Dr Ayine.</s>

en: Disagreeing with positions that the Chief Justice should withdraw the complaint and that he has no locus to file such a complaint, Mr Ndebugre said Dr Ayine was not talking about an individual member of the panel or the members of the panel who were just seven. He wasn't talking about combination of them. He talked about the whole judiciary and the Chief Justice is the head of the judiciary and therefore he was the proper person to lay the complaint.
twi: Mr Ndebugre kyerɛ sɛ ɔne wɔn a wɔse ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa ntwe ne kwaadu a ɔde abɔ Dr Ayine nsan no nyɛ adwene. ɔkyerɛ sɛ, Dr Ayine asɛm no ɔkaeɛ no ankɔ amma ɔtemmuafoɔ no mu baako anaa atemmuafoɔ mpaninfoɔ nson a wɔdii asɛm no. Na ɔrekasa afa aban mmara adwumakuo no nyinaa ho ɛnna ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa nso na ɔda aban mmara adwuma no ano, nti ɔno ne nipa ɛwɔ sɛ ɔde kwaadu bɔ Dr Ayine.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no nsɛm a wɔde too gua no ho ne sɛ ɔmanpanin no nsɛm no bɛkɔ so no, Ndebugre kae sɛ Dr Ayine nkae no yɛ ɔmanpanin no mu no.</s>

en: Speaking in a radio interview monitored by Graphic Online on Accra based Citi FM on Tuesday evening (June 22, 2021), Mr Ndebugre said: "I think that there is no problem about the Chief Justice laying the complaint."
twi: ɔne Citi FM a wɔwɔ Accra ntwetwe nkɔmmɔ no Benada anwummerɛ (Kotonomma da a ɛtɔ so aduonu mmienu wɔ 2021 muɔ, Mr Ndebugre kaa sɛ, “megye di sɛ mfomsoɔ biara nni ho sɛ ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa de kwaadu bɛbɔ no.”
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ, "Nni ɔhaw biara wɔ Chief Justice no sɛ ɔbɛkyerɛ nnipa a ɔyɛ ɔman panin no."</s>

en: Comparing that to what happened in 1996 - the Republic against Mensah Bonsu, Stephen Quarcoo and Tommy Thompson - in that case Mensah Bonsu attacked an individual judge, Justice Abban and therefore he made the complaint and then the Attorney-General took it up from there and prosecuted the matter on behalf of the judiciary or the court.
twi: ɔde deɛ ɛsii 1996 reyɛ mfatoho no – ɔman no de kwaadu bɔɔ Mensah Bonsu, Stephen Quarɔoo ne Tommy Thompson a wɔkyerɛ sɛ Mensah Bonsu akasa atia Justice Aban nti wɔbɔɔ no kwaadu, ɛnna aban lɔya panin gyinaa aban mmara adwuma no anan mu wɔ kɔɔto.
mt0: <pad> Ɛho nsɛm no yɛ a, ɛwɔ 1996 mu - Republic against Mensah Bonsu, Stephen Quarcoo and Tommy Thompson - wɔ saa ɔkwan no so, Mensah Bonsu kɔtwee ɔmanpanin bi, Justice Abban, na ɛno nti ɔde ɔkyerɛkyerɛfoɔ no bɛkaeɛ no na ɔde ɔkwan no kɔɔ so wɔ ɔmanpanin no anaa ɔmanpanin no ase.</s>

en: No problem about CJ filing complaint
twi: ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa no mfom mmara sɛ ɔde kwaadu bɛbɔ no.
mt0: <pad> No problem about CJ filing a lawsuit.</s>

en: "So I think that there is no problem about the Chief Justice laying the complaint.
twi: “Nti medwene sɛ mfomsoɔ biara nni ho sɛ ɔtemmuafoɔ panin paa de kwaadu bɛbɔ no.”
mt0: <pad> "So I think there is no problem about the Chief Justice laying the complaint.</s>

en: The other matter is that, Dominic Ayine was Deputy Attorney-General, and he and his boss at that time took people to the criminal court, proceeding to the civil court... so if the Attorney-General approves the prosecution of a person, can somebody say that no, the person was expressing freedom of speech... therefore he should not be sent to court.
twi: Deɛ ɛdi hɔ ne sɛ, na Dominic Ayine yɛ aban lɔya abadiakyire na saa mmerɛ no na ɔne ne panin de nkorɔfoɔ kɔ kɔɔto ... nti sɛ aban lɔya panin ka sɛ wɔmfa onipa korɔ no nnyina mmara anim a, obi bɛtumi aka sɛ, na saa nipa korɔ no rekyerɛ n’adwene nti mma wɔmfa no nkɔ kɔɔto?
mt0: <pad> Ɔkwan foforo ne sɛ, Dominic Ayine yɛ Deputy Attorney-General, na ɔ ne ne boss no kɔɔ criminal court, kɔɔ civil court... ɛno nti sɛ Attorney-General no gye sɛ wɔkyere obi, a ɛbɛtumi aba sɛ obi yɛ freedom of speech... ɛno nti ɛsɛ sɛ wɔmma no kwaadu.</s>

en: No, you are to go to the court and make your case, and state your case, and say that you were not guilty of the offence charged.

en: The National Peace Council (NPC) has initiated measures to deepen national unity by tackling the polarisation of the country in the aftermath of last year’s general election.
twi: Nsɛnsɛm a ɛbaeɛ wɔ abatoɔ a wɔtoo abatoɔ no afe a ɛtwaam no akyi no, National peace Council (NPC) de nhyehyɛeɛ agu akwan mu sɛ wɔbɛboa ama nkabom aba ɔman no mu.
mt0: <pad> National Peace Council (NPC) no ayɛ nhyehyɛe sɛ wɔbɛkɔ so ntɔkwa a ɛbɛma aman no ntam nnipadua mu a, na wɔbɛbɔ mmɔden sɛ wɔbɛkyere polarisation a ɛwɔ aman no mu a ɛbaeɛ a ɛkɔɔ so afe yi mu.</s>

en: According to the council, political polarisation was a major issue that had the potential to bring about a crisis situation, hence the need to nip it in the bud.

en: Participants included the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth Secretariat, the Rt Hon. Patricia Scotland; the UNDP Resident Representative, Dr Angela Lusigi; the ministers of Information, Mr Kojo Oppong Nkrumah; the Interior, Mr Ambrose Dery, and National Security, Mr Albert Kan-Dapaah.
twi: Wɔn wɔbaa dwumadie yi ase ne Commonwealth ɔtwerɛtwerɛfoɔ panin, Rt. Hon. Patricia Sɔotland; UNDP ananmusifoɔ, Dr Angela Lusigi; ɔsoafoɔ a ɔhwɛ nkitahodie so, Mr Kojo Oppong; amannwoeɛ soafoɔ, Mr Ambrose Dery ne ɔsoafoɔ a ɔhwɛ ɔman mmammɔ so, Mr Albert Kan-Dapaah.
mt0: <pad> Wɔn a wɔkɔɔ no ne Commonwealth Secretariat Secretary-General, Rt Hon. Patricia Scotland; UNDP Resident Representative, Dr Angela Lusigi; Information Minister, Mr Kojo Oppong Nkrumah; Interior, Mr Ambrose Dery, and National Security, Mr Albert Kan-Dapaah.</s>

en: Others were a Deputy Chairperson of the Electoral Commission, Dr Eric Bossman Asare; a representative of the Inspector-General of Police, some executive members of the National Democratic Congress, the New Patriotic Party, the Convention People's Party, faith-based organisations, traditional rulers and civil society organisations.
twi: Wɔne a na wɔwɔ hɔ bio ne abatoɔ kɔmisa abadiakyire, Dr Eric Bossman Asare; apolisifoɔ panin paa namusifoɔ, National Democratic Congress, New PatrioticParty, ɔonvention People’s Party mpaninfoɔ, asɔfo mpaninfoɔ, ahemfo ne akuo ahodoɔ a wɔwɔ ɔman no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanfoɔ a wɔwɔ hɔ no ne Deputy Chairman of the Electoral Commission, Dr Eric Bossman Asare; a representative of the Inspector-General of Police, some executive members of the National Democratic Congress, the New Patriotic Party, the Convention People's Party, faith-based organisations, traditional rulers and civil society organisations.</s>

en: Mr Dery said notwithstanding the security strategies that were put in place ahead of the December general election, there were still some pockets of violent incidents which claimed some lives and led to the destruction to property.
twi: Mr Dery kaa sɛ ɛmfa ho ne nhyehyɛeɛ bammɔ adwumakuo de guu akwan ɛfa abatoɔ no ho no, basabasaeɛ ahodoɔ kɔɔ so a nnipa binom hweree wɔn nkwa, ɛnna agyapadeɛ ahodoɔ nso sɛe.
mt0: <pad> Ɔsahene Dery kaa sɛ, ɛmfa ho sɛ wɔde ɔkwan ahodoɔ ayɛ wɔ ɔman no mu ansa na ɔman no bɛgyinae no a, ɛwɔ mmeaeɛ a ɛyɛ hu a ɛkyeree nkwan ne adeɛ a ɛkɔɔ so.</s>

en: He said 32 violent incidents were recorded by the police in five constituencies across the country, out of which six persons died.
twi: ɔkyerɛɛ sɛ basabasaeɛ ho nsɛm aduasa mmienu na ɛsii wɔn abatoɔ mpasua nnum mu wɔ ɔman no mu a, nnipa baasia hweree wɔn nkwa.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaeɛ sɛ, nnipa 32 na wɔkyeree wɔ aman a ɛwɔ ɔman no mu a wɔde kɔɔ so no, a nnipa 6 na wɔwui.</s>

en: Mr Dery said the government would not relent in its effort to get those behind the disturbances to face prosecution.
twi: Mr Dery de too dwa sɛ aban reyɛ nhwehwɛmu afa basabasaeɛ yi ho na wɔn a wɔhyɛ aseɛ no, wɔbɛtwe wɔn aso.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin Dery kaa sɛ ɔmanpanin no bɛnkɔ so yɛ adwuma sɛ ɔbɛma wɔn a wɔde ɔhaw no bae no adi ɔmmoa.</s>

en: For his part, Mr Kan-Dapaah said political tolerance and consensus building remained critical ingredients for the social, economic and political advancement of the country.
twi: Mr Kan-Dapaah nso de too dwa sɛ, sɛ ɔman no bɛtu mpɔn a, ɛgyina sɛ amanyɔkuo ahodoɔ no rete wɔn ho ase so.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ, ɔbɛyɛ adeɛ a ɛho hia paa na ɔbɛyɛ adeɛ a ɛho hia paa ma ɔman no kɔ anim.</s>

en: The Rt Hon. Scotland commended the people of Ghana for the peaceful manner in which they engaged in political discourse in the country, which she said was acknowledged by the entire Commonwealth family.
twi: Rt Hon Sɔotland bɔɔ Ghanafoɔ aba wɔ asomdwoeɛ kwan a wɔfaa so too aba wɔ ɔman no mu. ɛkyerɛ Commonwealthabusuakuo no ani gyee ho pa ara.
mt0: <pad> Rt Hon. Scotland kaa Ghanafoɔ no ho asɛm sɛ wɔde nteaseɛ ayɛ wɔ amanneɛbɔ mu wɔ Ghana, a ɔkaeɛ sɛ Commonwealth abusuakuo no nyinaa gye di.</s>

en: According to her, Ghana had historically led the way in democracy, which she said was "a heavy burden on the people’s shoulders, but it’s a burden that the people have carried with pride. We have always hoped in Ghana".
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ, Ghana akɔ n’anim wɔ kabimamenkabi amammuo mu a ɔkyerɛɛ sɛ, “ɛyɛ adesoa a ɛda kuromma no so, nso saa kuromma no abɔ wɔn ho mmɔden yie. Yɛwɔ awerɛhyɛmu kɛseɛ wɔ Ghana mu.”
mt0: <pad> Ghana ayɛ ɔman a ɛdi kan wɔ democracy mu, nanso sɛ ɔkae sɛ "nnipa no nsa bɛyɛ den, nanso nnipa no de ne ho adi nkonim. Yɛde yɛn ani gye Ghana".</s>

en: She, however, called for the inclusion of more women and the youth in policy formulation in the country.
twi: ɔsan nso de too dwa sɛ ɛyɛ mmaa ne mmabunu no de wɔn ho hyɛ ɔman no mmarahyɛ mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ɛsɛ sɛ mmaa ne mmofra no bɛkɔ wɔ amanneɛbɔ mu wɔ ɔman no mu.</s>

en: The Chairman of the NPC, Rev. Dr Ernest Adu-Gyamfi, said his outfit was working at strengthening mechanisms for inter- and intra-party dialogue to deepen trust and confidence in key state institutions responsible for elections.
twi: ɔtitenani a ɔda NPɔ ano, Rev. Dr. Ernest Adu-Gyamfi de too dwa sɛ, saa dwumadie yi de ayɔnkofa, gyidie ne awerɛhyɛmu mapa bɛba amanyɔkuo ahodoɔ no ntam ne ɔman nnwumakuo a ɛhwɛ abatoɔ so wɔ ɔman no mu ntam.
mt0: <pad> NPC Chairman, Rev. Dr Ernest Adu-Gyamfi, said his outfit was working on strengthening mechanisms for inter- and intra-party dialogue to deepen trust and confidence in key state institutions responsible for elections.</s>

en: He expressed the hope that the issues discussed would significantly contribute to the healing of wounds created in the aftermath of the 2020 elections.
twi: ɔkyerɛ sɛ saa nkɔmmɔdie yi bɛboa ama wɔasiesie ɔhaw a aba 202 abatoɔ akyi no nyinaa.
mt0: <pad> Ɔde n'ani gye ho sɛ ɔbɛboa ama ayɛ no mu ɔhaw a ɛwɔ 2020 abatoɔ akyi no.</s>

en: The Chief Servant of Transeco Minerals and Mining, Mr. Godwin Amarh has constructed a six-unit classroom block at Akyem Ampapatia in the Atiwa West District of the Eastern Region.
twi: ɔpanin paa ɔda Transeco Mineral ne Mining ano, Mr. Godwin Amarh asi sukuu dan adampɔn nsia wɔ Akyem Ampapatia a ɛwɔ Atiwa West mansini a ɛwɔ Apueeɛ mantam mu.
mt0: <pad> Transeco Minerals and Mining, Mr. Godwin Amarh, a ɔyɛ adwumayɛfoɔ no Chief Servant, has constructed a six-unit classroom block at Akyem Ampapatia in the Atiwa West District of the Eastern Region.</s>

en: The classroom block, estimated at a cost of GH¢295,000 forms part of the company’s Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR).
twi: ɔbɔɔ ka GH¢295,000 wɔ saa sukuu adan yi ho; na wei ka kɔmpɛne nhyehyɛeɛ ho sɛ wɔbɛboa ama wɔn atenaeɛ mu atu mpɔn.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkyerɛkyerɛ no, a wɔde sika bɛyɛ GH¢295,000, yɛ adwumakuw no CSR dwumadie.</s>

en: Speaking at the inauguration, Mr Amarh underscored the need to give good and quality education to children at lower levels as it helps to give them strong foundation in education.
twi: Wɔrebue dan no ano no, Mr Amarh kyerɛɛ sɛdeɛ ɛhia sɛ mmɔfra a wɔwɔ mfiaseɛ sukuu mu bɛnya nwomasua mapa ɛsiane sɛ ɛboa ma wɔnya nwomasua mu fapem papa.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa wɔ ɔyɛkyerɛ no mu, Mr Amarh kyerɛɛ sɛ ɛho hia sɛ wɔma mmofra adesua a ɛyɛ papa wɔ lower level esiane sɛ ɛboa ma wɔnya adeɛ a ɛyɛ papa wɔ adesua mu.</s>

en: He said the role of education in every country’s development cannot be undermined, hence the reason his company prioritizes education.
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ, wɔntumi ntoto nwomasua aseɛ wɔ kwa biara so ɛsiane sɛ ɔman no mpontuo gyina nwomasua so, nti ɛho hia sɛ kɔmpɛne no nso bɛma nwomasua ahia wɔn.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ adesua ntumi mma ɔman biara kɔ anim, ɛno nti na ɔde adeyɛ no bɛdi kan wɔ ne nnwumakuw no mu.</s>

en: “We at Transeco Mining and Minerals Company have decided to ensure that children in communities where we operate are exposed to the best of teaching and learning environments at the lower levels of education. That is why we have made education a top priority on our corporate social responsibility.
twi: “Yɛn a yɛyɛ adwuma wɔ Transeco Mining and Minerals companyayɛ yɛn adwene sɛ, yɛbɛboa ama mfiaaseɛ sukuu nwomasua atu mpɔn wɔ baabibiara yɛn dwumakuo yi bi wɔ. Wei nti na dwumakuo ayɛ n’adwene sɛ ɔbɛboa ama nwomasua atu mpɔn wɔ baabi biara wɔwɔ.”
mt0: <pad> “Yɛn wɔ Transeco Mining and Minerals Company no de yɛn adwene abɛyɛ sɛ mmofra a wɔwɔ mmeae a yɛkɔ so no bɛnya adesua a ɛyɛ papa wɔ ɔmantam a yɛkɔ so no. Esiane saa nti na yɛde adesua ayɛ top priority wɔ yɛn corporate social responsibility no mu.</s>

en: I’m excited to be back at Ampapatia to commission this school. We all know how important education is to the growth of individuals and the country. In order to have brilliant students at higher levels of education, they must first have a strong foundation that is why we have built this Kindergarten”, he said.
twi: ɔkaa sɛ, “ɛyɛ me dɛ sɛ maba Ampapatia na merebɛbue saa sukuu yi ano. Yɛn nyinaa yɛnim sɛdeɛ nwomasua ho hia ma nnipa ne ɔman no mpontuo. Sɛ yɛbɛnya asuafoɔ ama wɔaka sukuu aduruu akyire a, ɛwɔ sɛ wɔnya fapem mapa, na wei nti na ama yɛasi saa sukuu dan yi.”
mt0: <pad> Nna a, me ani gye ho sɛ mɛsan aba Ampapatia sɛ mɛyɛ saa sukuu no. Yɛnnim sɛ adesua hia nnipa ne aman no. Sɛ yɛbɛnya adesuafo a wɔn nsa bɛka wɔn adeɛ a, ɛsɛ sɛ wɔwɔ asɔre a ɛyɛ den ansa na wɔanya adesua a ɛyɛ den.</s>

en: Mr. Amarh said the school is also an appreciation to the chiefs and people of Ampapatia who have maintained a healthy relationship with the company since they started their operations in the community.
twi: Mr Amarh de kaa ho sɛ, sukuu dan no yɛ aseda a wɔde rema ahemfo ne nnipa a wɔwɔ Ampapatia mu a wɔne adwumakuo no anya nkitahodie mapa firi berɛ adwumakuo baa wɔn mpɔtam mu no.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Amarh kyerɛɛ sɛ sukuu no yɛ nkuran ma Ampapatia mpaninfo ne nkurofo a wɔwɔ ɔman no mu a wɔde wɔn ho adi dwuma firi bere a wɔfii aseɛ wɔn adwumayɛbeaeɛ no mu.</s>

en: Contrary to rumors and wild speculations that government has placed a ban on mining activities in the country, Mr. Amarh debunked the rumours and described it as not just inaccurate but false.
twi: Mr Amarh de too dwa sɛ ɛnyɛ nokorɛ sɛ aban no de taaboɔ ato maenen so wɔ ɔman no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɛmfa ho sɛ nsɛm ne wild speculations a ɛwɔ hɔ sɛ aban no de ban kɔkɔbɔ dwumadie wɔ ɔman no mu no, Mr. Amarh debunked the rumours and described it as not just inaccurate but false.</s>

en: According to him, government has rather introduced new measures, policies and programmes aimed at making small scale mining productive and not destructive.
twi: ɔkyerɛ sɛ aban no mmom de nhyehyɛeɛ mapa aba sɛdeɛ maenen bɛtu mpɔn, na nyɛ sɛ ɔbɛgu no.
mt0: <pad> According to him, government has rather introduced new measures, policies and programmes aimed at making small scale mining productive and not destructive.</s>

en: “Government has not banned activities of miners but rather categorized areas close to water bodies and forest reserves as red zones where no individual or company should mine. So what government is saying is that small scale miners should move away from the red zones. So anyone who does contrary to the directive by government will be dealt with by the laws of the country”, Mr. Amarh said.
twi: Mr Amarh kaa sɛ, “Aban mfaa taaboɔ ntoo maenen na mmom wɔkyerɛ beaeɛ ahodoɔ a ɛbɛn nsuo ne kwaeɛ no mu baabi a ɛnni kwan sɛ obiara kɔyɛ maenen dwumadie biara wɔ hɔ. Nti obiara a ɔbɛbu aban nhyehyɛeɛ yi so no, mmara ne no bɛdi.”
mt0: <pad> “Amanfoɔ no nsii sɛ wɔbɛyɛ adeɛ a ɛho hia nanso amanfoɔ no de red zones a ɛwɔ mmeaeɛ a ɛbɛn nsuo ne mmeaeɛ a ɛyɛ nnuaba a wɔde kɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ akɔtɔ

en: He therefore advised small scale miners to go work but ensure that they mine at designated areas.
twi: ɔtuu wɔn a wɔyɛ maenen adwuma no fo sɛ, wɔkɔtu maenen no na mmom wɔnyɛ no beaeɛ a wɔahyɛ wɔn no no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkyerɛɛ sɛ nnipa a wɔyɛ nnua a wɔde nsa bɛka no kɔ adwuma nanso ɛsɛ sɛ wɔkɔ nsuo mu wɔ beae a wɔahyehyɛ no.</s>

en: Mr. Amarh who also doubles as the General Secretary of the Ghana National Association of Small Scale Miners (GNASSM) admonished members of the group to impact positively on communities where they have concessions.
twi: Mr Amarh a ɔsan nso yɛ ɔtwerɛtwerɛfoɔ Panin ma Ghana National associationof Small Sɔale Miners (GNASSMɔ de too ne kuomma anim sɛ wɔmmoa mma mpɔtam a wɔyɛ wɔn adwuma wɔ mu no ntu mpɔn.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Amarh a ɔyɛ General Secretary of the Ghana National Association of Small Scale Miners (GNASSM) kaa kyerɛɛ nnipa a wɔwɔ kuo no sɛ wɔbɛma nsunsuansoɔ ma nkuro a wɔwɔ concessions no.</s>

en: He said small scale miners must work to change the narrative that they are destroyers who only take from communities and give nothing back.
twi: ɔde too dwa sɛ wɔn a wɔtu maenen no nsesa deɛ wɔka fa wɔn ho sɛ wɔsɛe mpɔtam ahodoɔ mu a mpɔtam no nnyaa hwee firi wɔn ho.

en: He said although many small scale miners are already doing that, there remains more to be done.
twi: ɔkyerɛɛ sɛ, maenenfoɔ no bi rebɔ wɔn ho mmɔden nso wɔbɛtumi ayɛ asene saa.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaeɛ sɛ, ɛwom sɛ nnipa bebree a wɔyɛ nnua a wɔde kɔ ɔman no mu no reyɛ saa, ɛwɔ adeɛ a ɛsɛ sɛ wɔyɛ.</s>

en: “Our sector employs a lot of people in communities where we operate. We must therefore work assiduously to leave a footprint. I know a lot of our members who have built schools and others have helped communities get electricity. We must push those stories out there to change the narrative that small scale miners only destroy’, he advised.
twi: ɔtoo fo sɛ, “Yɛn adwumakuo yi fa nnipa bebree wɔ mpɔtam ahodoɔ a yɛyɛ yɛn nnwuma no adwuma. ɛwɔ sɛ yɛyɛ adwumaden gya biribi papa to hɔ. Menim sɛ kuomma no dodoɔ no ara a wɔasisi sukuu adan na wɔaboa ma mpɔtam ahodoɔ anya anyinam ahoɔden. ɛwɔ sɛ yɛbɔ nsɛm yi ho dawuro ma nkorɔfoɔ sesa deɛ wɔka fa yɛn ho no.”

en: The Rebecca Foundation has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Abdul Samad Rabiu Africa Initiative (ASR Africa) for a grant of $500,000.
twi: Rebeɔɔa Foundation ne Abdul Samad Rabiu Africa Initiative (ASR Africa) de wɔn nsa ahyɛ kɔntraagye aseɛ a, sika a Rebeɔaa Foundation bɛnya yɛ $500,000.
mt0: <pad> Rebecca Foundation no de Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) kyerɛɛ Abdul Samad Rabiu Africa Initiative (ASR Africa) sɛ wɔbɛma sika a ɛyɛ $500,000.</s>

en: The grant will be drawn from ASR Africa’s annual $100 million Africa Fund for Social Development and Renewal to support the Rebecca Foundation’s education initiative.
twi: Saa sika yi bɛfiri ASR Africa afe mu no nyinaa dwetire watwa to hɔ ama Africa Fund for SocialDevelopment and Renewal a ɛyɛ dɔla no, ɔpepem ɔha mu na ɛbɛba de aboa Rebeɔɔa Foundation nwomasua ho nhyehyɛeɛ.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman no bɛgye sika a ɛyɛ $100 million firi ASR Africa's annual $100 million Africa Fund for Social Development and Renewal sɛ Rebecca Foundation bɛboa ɔman no sukuu dwumadie no.</s>

en: Speaking at the meeting, the Managing Director of ASR Africa, Mr Ubon Udoh, commended the foundation for its commitment to the welfare of women and children in the country.
twi: ɔde n’anodisɛm reto dwan wɔ nhyiamu no ase no, ASR Africa adwuma no kwankyerɛfoɔ, Mr Ubon Udoh bɔɔ ekuo yi aba so sɛ wɔatu wɔn ho asi hɔ ama mmaa ne mmɔfra mpontuo.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman panin a ɔdi ASR Africa, Mr Ubon Udoh, kaa wɔ nkitaho no mu sɛ ɔde ne ho ahyɛ foundation no so sɛ ɔbɛboa mmaa ne mmofra a wɔwɔ Ghana.</s>

en: He also praised the foundation for its adherence to good corporate governance and practices which have enabled the foundation to deliver infrastructure and services in the areas of education, health and women’s economic empowerment.
twi: ɔsan bɔɔ ekuo no aba wɔ sɛdeɛ wɔde amammuo mapa redi wɔn dwuma a aboa ama ekuo no reyɛ nnwuma bebree aboa ama nwomasua, apɔmmɔden nsɛm ne mmaa mpontuo rekɔ so.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ɔde n'ani akyerɛ foundation no sɛ ɛwɔ corporate governance ne practices a ɛboaa sɛ ɛbɛma infrastructure ne services wɔ education, health ne women’s economic empowerment areas.</s>

en: "We did our homework and identified the Rebecca Foundation as one of the most reputable charities in Ghana, which encouraged ASR Africa to support the Rebecca Foundation.” he said.
twi: ɔkaa sɛ, “Yɛyɛɛ yɛn nhwehwɛmu hunuu sɛ Rebeɔɔa Foundation yɛ adɔeɛ kuo a wɔn anim wɔ nyam wɔ Ghana, na ɛhyɛɛ ASR Africa nkuran sɛ yɛmmɛboa wɔn.”
mt0: <pad> "Yɛyɛɛ yɛn nhwehwɛmu na yɛde Rebecca Foundation ayɛ ɔmanfoɔ a wɔwɔ Ghana no mu baako, ɛno nti ASR Africa de Rebecca Foundation ho kɔmmɔe."</s>

en: The Executive Director of the Foundation, Mrs Rebecca Akufo-Addo, thanked ASR Africa for the support to the foundation.
twi: Kwankyerɛfoɔ a ɔda Rebeɔɔa Foundation ano, Mrs Rebeɔɔa Akufo-Addo daa ASR Africa ase wɔ wɔn mmoa wɔde aboa ekuo no.
mt0: <pad> Ɔman panin a ɔyɛ Foundation no Executive Director, Mrs Rebecca Akufo-Addo, de ɔsom ASR Africa a wɔboaa ɔman panin no.</s>

en: She pledged the commitment of the foundation to utilise the grant to benefit the education of children in the country.
twi: ɔhyɛɛ bɔ sɛ ekuo no de sika no bɛboa ama mmɔfra nwomasua atu mpɔn wɔ ɔman no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔde ɔyɛkyerɛ no sɛ ɔbɛfa sika no a wɔde mae no akɔ so ama mmofra a wɔwɔ ɔman no adesua ho.</s>

en: The UK has denied involvement in the arrest and extradition of Nnamdi Kanu, who leads a banned group seeking a breakaway state in south-eastern Nigeria, where the ethnic Igbo people form the majority.
twi: UK aban no kyerɛ sɛ, wɔnnim Nnamdi Kanu a ɔdi nnipadɔm a wɔwɔ Nigeria anaafoɔ apueeɛ fam a Igbofoɔ ma wɔdɔɔso wɔ hɔ no kyere ne bɔ a wɔabɔ no aba Nigeria no ho hwee.
mt0: <pad> UK no nsii wɔn ho sɛ wɔde wɔn ho bɛkaa Nnamdi Kanu, a ɔyɛ ɔmanfo a ɔpɛ sɛ ɔkɔ ɔman foforo a ɛwɔ Nigeria apueefam, a Igbo nnipa no yɛ ɔmanfo dodoɔ.</s>

en: Mr Kanu, who holds British and Nigerian citizenship, was detained on Sunday with the help of Interpol and flown back to Nigeria, according to the attorney general.
twi: Aban lɔya panin kyerɛ sɛ, Interpol kyee Mr Kanu a ɔyɛ Britainni na ɔsan nso firi Nigeria Kwasiada de no baa Nigeria.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin Kanu, a ɔwɔ British ne Nigerian mantam, na wɔde no kɔɔ Nigeria anadwo no mu wɔ Interpol ase na wɔde no kɔɔ Nigeria, ɛkaa ɔmanpanin general.</s>

en: He faces treason-related charges in Nigeria, but fled the country in 2017 while on bail.
twi: Wɔde tirisin kwaadu bɔɔ no wɔ Nigeria wɔ 2017 mu nso wɔdwanee firii ɔman no mu berɛ a wɔmaa no beele.
mt0: <pad> Ɔwɔ treason charges wɔ Nigeria, nanso ɔfirii ɔman no afe 2017 bere a ɔwɔ bail.</s>

en: There has been speculation that he might have been arrested in the UK, where it is believed he was mainly based.

en: “We can confirm that Nnamdi Kanu was not arrested in the UK for extradition purposes,’’ a British High Commission spokesperson told the BBC.

en: His trial is expected to resume on 26 July.

en: The 53-year-old came to prominence in 2009 when he started Radio Biafra and broadcast to Nigeria from London, using the platform to call for Biafran independence and urging his followers to take up arms against the Nigerian state.
twi: Nnamdi Kanu gyee ne din wɔ 2009 mu berɛ a ɔhyɛɛ Radio Biafra adwuma ase wɔ London a na ɛba Nigeria. Sɛdeɛ wɔn a wɔte Biafra bɛnya wɔn fahodie nti, ɔde saa akwannya yi de too wɔn a wɔdi n’akyi no sɛ wɔtwetwe atuo wɔn Nigeria man no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔbɔɔ amanneɛbɔ wɔ 2009 bere a ɔyɛɛ Radio Biafra na ɔde kɔɔ Nigeria firii London, de n'akyi no bɛkaa sɛ Biafranfoɔ nnipadua ne ɔman no bɛdi asogyafoɔ ho dwuma.</s>

en: Five years later, he founded the Indigenous People of Biafra (Ipob), which has since been labelled a terrorist organisation by the Nigerian authorities.

en: The Institute of Directors-Ghana (IoD-Gh) has commended the Bank of Ghana (BoG) for taking significant steps to promote good corporate governance in the country.
twi: Institute of Directors-Ghana (IoD-Gh) abɔ Bank of Ghana (BoG) aba so wɔ nhyehyɛeɛ mapa a wɔde agu akwan mu sɛdeɛ adwumakuo a wɔwɔ ɔman no mu ho bɛdwo wɔn.
mt0: <pad> Institute of Directors-Ghana (IoD-Gh) ayɛ nkuran ma Bank of Ghana (BoG) sɛ ɛbɛdi dwuma a ɛho hia paa sɛ ɛbɛboa corporate governance wɔ Ghana.</s>

en: It has also called for stronger collaboration between the institute and the bank to help promote proper governance of companies in the country.
twi: Wɔasrɛ sɛ wɔne Bank of Ghana bɛnya ayɔnkofa soronko a ɛbɛboa ama adwumakuo wɔwɔ ɔman no mu amammuo bɛtu mpɔn.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ɛsɛ sɛ adwumakuw no ne bank no yɛ adwuma mu wɔn ho sɛdeɛ ɛbɛboa ma ɔman no akɔ so yɛ adwuma yiye.</s>

en: During a courtesy by the institute on the management of BoG, the President of IoD-Gh, Mr Rockson Kwesi Dogbegah, eulogised the Governor of the central bank, Dr Ernest Addison, for providing transformational leadership in reforming the financial services sector.
twi: Berɛ a wɔkɔsraa BoG manɛgɛmɛnt no, ɔpanin a ɔda IoD-Gh ano, Mr. Roɔkson Kwesi Dogbegah bɔɔ Bank of Ghana panin paa, Dr Ernest Addison no aba so wɔ n’amammuo papa ɔde abu sikasɛm akuo ahodoɔ wɔ ɔman no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin a ɔdi kan no, Mr Rockson Kwesi Dogbegah, sɛdeɛ ɔkɔɔ nsrahwɛ wɔ BoG no mu no, ɔkaeɛ sɛ ɔma leadership a ɛyɛ transformational wɔ financial services sector no mu.</s>

en: He said the effort by BoG led by Dr Addison had led to a vibrant and resilient banking sector.
twi: ɔkyerɛ sɛ BoG a Dr Addison da ano no aboa ma sikakorabea a ɛwɔ ɔman no mu ntotoeɛ atu mpɔn.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaeɛ sɛ BoG no dwumadie a Dr Addison de too gua no ama ɔman no nkɔmmɔ ne nteaseɛ a ɛyɛ den.</s>

en: A statement from the institute said the visit was to commend the bank for its significant role in promoting the culture of good corporate governance in Ghana and to seek mutually beneficial relationships between BoG and the institute.
twi: Asɛm a adwumakuo mpaninfoɔ yi de too dwa fa deɛ nti a wɔkɔɔ BoG ne sɛ, wɔrekɔbɔ wɔn aba wɔ kwan a wɔafa so atoto adwumakuo ho ammmuo wɔ Ghana na wɔpɛ sɛ wɔne BoG ayɔnkofa no gyina pintinn.
mt0: <pad> Ghana Institute of Good Governance (GIBC) kyerɛ sɛ, ɔkɔɔ BoG no sɛ ɔbɛkae n'adwene wɔ corporate governance ho adeɛ a ɛyɛ papa wɔ Ghana.</s>

en: Speaking on the strategic projects of the IoD-Gh, Mr Dogbegah said the IoD-Gh is developing a charter aimed at setting standards for the practice of corporate governance in Ghana.
twi: ɔrekasa afa nhyehyɛeɛ a IoD-Gh de agu akwan mu no, Mr Dogbegah kyerɛ sɛ IoD-Gh de nhyehyɛeɛ regu akwan mu sɛdeɛ ɛbɛyɛ nnwumakuo mu amammuo bɛtu mpɔn wɔ ɔman no mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ IoD-Gh nsɛm a wɔreyɛ no ho, Mr Dogbegah kaa sɛ IoD-Gh reyɛ a charter a ɛbɛma Ghana akɔ so anya corporate governance.</s>

en: He indicated that the development of a national governance code was another key strategic project to be undertaken by the institute.
twi: ɔkyerɛ sɛ ɔman mu amammuo kɔɔdo nso yɛ nhyehyɛeɛ baako a wɔde regu akwan mu.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ ɔbɛyɛ adeɛ a ɛho hia paa sɛ wɔbɛyɛ ɔman no nnisoɔ ɔkwan.</s>

en: He disclosed that the institute had established the ongoing annual corporate governance excellence awards as part of its strategic efforts to celebrate the achievements of outstanding individual personalities and corporate organisations that have represented excellence in leadership and corporate governance and have made significant contributions to the socioeconomic development of Ghana.
twi: ɔdaa no adi sɛ afe biara no, wɔbɛbɔ nnipa ahodoɔ ne nnwumakuo a wɔn adwuma sɔ ani no wɔ nnwumakuo amammuo mu na wɔaboa ama mpontuo aba ɔman no mu aba so.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ, ɔde n'adwene bɛyɛɛ sɛ ɔbɛyɛ adeɛ a ɛho hia wɔ Ghana economy mu no sɛ ɔbɛyɛ adeɛ a ɛho hia wɔ Ghana economy mu no.</s>

en: He added that the Institute, working in collaboration with key stakeholders, had championed the formation of the Ghana Association of Integrated Thinking and Reporting aimed at stimulating a strategic and sustainable way of value creation and reporting by organisations.
twi: ɔde kaa ho sɛ adwumakuo ne ne nnwumakuo ahodoɔ aka wɔn ho abɔm ate Ghana associationof Integrated Thinking and Reporting a ɛbɛboa ama nnwumakuo aba nyam.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ, Ghana Institute of Integrated Thinking and Reporting (GAIR) no yɛ adwuma wɔ collaboration with key stakeholders, sɛdeɛ ɛbɛma nnipa a wɔwɔ ɔkwan a wɔbɛyɛ adeɛ ne nsɛm a wɔbɛkyerɛ nsɛm no anya kɔanim na wɔbɛkyerɛ nsɛm no.</s>

en: BoG Governor stated that corporate governance played an important role in the financial sector.
twi: Panin paa ɔda BoG ano de too dwa sɛ nnwumakuo amammuo di akotene yie wɔ sikasɛm nnwumakuo mu.
mt0: <pad> BoG Governor kaa sɛ corporate governance yɛ adwuma a ɛho hia paa wɔ financial sector no mu.</s>

en: According to him, corporate governance breaches, overbearing shareholder behaviour and related-party transactional breaches as some of the factors that led to the failure of some banks in the financial sector and their consequent resolution.

en: Caps United chairman Lewis Uriri says they have resolved the problems facing their club and the striking players have begun preparations for their Castle Premier Soccer League matches.

mt0: <pad> Captain Lewis Uriri says they have resolved the problems facing their club and the striking players have begun preparations for their Castle Premier Soccer League matches.</s>

en: Speaking to Studio 7, Uriri said the players were given their outstanding bonus money.
twi: ɔne Studio 7 retwetwe nkɔmmɔ no, ɔde too dwa sɛ wɔatua bɔɔlɔbɔfoɔ sika a na akam no ama wɔn.
mt0: <pad> Uriri kyerɛɛ Studio 7, sɛ nnipa no wɔayɛ wɔn outstanding bonus money.</s>

en: But he said last month's salaries would be paid to players soon. He also mentioned that there were some unnamed people who were influencing Caps United players to stop playing football.
twi: Nso ɔde too dwa sɛ bosome a atwam no akatua deɛ, ɛnkyɛ biara wɔde bɛma wɔn. ɔsan nso kyerɛɛ sɛ nnipa bi a wɔnnim wɔn din redaadaa ɔaps United bɔɔlɔbɔfoɔ no sɛ mma wɔnsi akan.
mt0: <pad> Ɔkaa sɛ wɔbɛtua nnipa no sika a wɔde kɔɔ so no, nanso ɔkaa sɛ wɔbɛtua nnipa no sika a wɔde kɔɔ so no.</s>

en: Uriri said he had spoken to the players and also said the reason for the delay in paying the players was that things were difficult for everyone in the country and that the real government had not paid last year's bonuses.
twi: Utiri de too dwa sɛ deɛn nti na na bɔɔlɔbɔfoɔ nsa nkaa wɔn akatua ne sɛ na nnoɔma mu ayɛ den ama obiara wɔ ɔman no mu, na na aban no mpo mfaa wɔn sika mmaa wɔn.
mt0: <pad> Uriri kaa sɛ ɔkaa ne agodifo no ho nanso kaa sɛ nti a wɔde sika kɔɔ so no yɛ den sɛ nnipa nyinaa wɔ ɔman no mu no na ɛno nti a wɔde sika kɔɔ so no yɛ den sɛ ɔman no mu no nnipa nyinaa nni ɔman no mu na ɛwɔ ɔman no mu no.</s>

en: Sexual rights activists say abortion laws need to be amended to keep up with the times and to protect the lives of girls and women.
twi: Wɔn a wɔpere sɛ nsesaeɛ ba nnamusɛm ho kyerɛ sɛ, ɛwɔ sɛ wɔyɛ nsesaeɛ wɔ abɔɔhyin mmara na ɛne nnɛ mmerɛ mu abrabɔ no kɔ, na afei nso, ɛbɔ mmaayewa ne mmaa ho ban.
mt0: <pad> Sexual rights activists kae sɛ abortion mmara no hia sɛ wɔbɛyɛ nsakrae sɛ ɛbɛkɔ so nnɛ ne sɛ ɛbɛboa mmaa ne mmaa nkwa.</s>

en: Sayendisa Ndlovu of SayWhat says the public is unaware of the abortion law and says it is important for the government to publicize the law.
twi: Sayendisa Ndlovu a ɔka SayWhat ho kyerɛ sɛ, nnipa a wɔwɔ ɔman no mu dodoɔ no ara nnim abɔɔhyin mmara no nti ɛwɔ sɛ aban no bɔ ho dawuro kyerɛ amansan.
mt0: <pad> Sayendisa Ndlovu of SayWhat says the public is unaware of the abortion law and says it is important for the government to publicize the law.</s>

en: Ndlovu told Studio 7 that it was important to amend the law as it was written long ago. He said the law needed to be amended to add other factors that could lead to a miscarriage.
twi: Ndlove de too Studio 7 sɛ ɛhia sɛ wɔyɛ nsesaeɛ wɔ abɔɔhyin mmara mu ɛsiane sɛ wɔtwerɛɛ saa mmara no akyɛ.
mt0: <pad> Ndlovu kaa sɛ ɛho hia sɛ wɔbɛsane saa mmara no ase esiane sɛ ɛyɛ mfeɛ pii na wɔde sii no.</s>

en: Ndlovu said such factors as mental illness, HIV / AIDS or disability were some of the factors that could be considered for abortion.
twi: Ndlove kyerɛ sɛ adwenem haw, HIV/AIDS ne dɛnnie bi na na ɛma ho kwan ma obi yɛ abɔɔhyin.
mt0: <pad> Ndlovu kaa sɛ nnipa a wɔwɔ ɔhaw bi te sɛ ɔhaw a ɛyɛ hu, HIV/AIDS anaa nkwadaa ne adeɛ a ɛbɛtumi ama wɔn nsa aka sɛ wɔbɛgye wɔn nkwa no.</s>

en: Ndlovu also explained that the law as it stands does not limit public hospitals to public abortion services and did not require a child nurse or doctor to abort a person legally.
twi: Ndlovu kyerɛɛ mu sɛ mmara no sɛdeɛ ɛteɛ no nsi ayaresabea biara ho kwan wɔ abɔɔhyin nhyehyɛeɛ ho na mmara ma ho kwan sɛ nɛɛse anaa dɔkota bi bɛyɛ abɔɔhyin.
mt0: <pad> Ndlovu nso kaa sɛ mmara no nkyerɛ sɛ ɔmanfo ayaresabea nni tumi sɛ wɔbɛyɛ abortion adeɛ na ɛnsɛ sɛ mmofra nnamfo anaa ɔyarefo bɛyɛ abort nnipa a wɔnnim.</s>

en: Ms. Tendaishe Changamire, a civil rights activist under the Right Here Right Now program, has also called for the law to be amended to increase the risk of abortion.
twi: Ms. Tendaishe ɔhangamire a ɔpere nsesaeɛ wɔ ɔman mma fahodie ho nso de too dwa wɔ Right Here Right Now dwumadie so sɛ, ɛwɔ sɛ nsesaeɛ ba abɔɔhyin mmara no mu sɛdeɛ ɛbɛma abɔɔhyinyɛ so ate.
mt0: <pad> Ms. Tendaishe Changamire, a ɔyɛ civil rights activist wɔ Right Here Right Now program no, nso de nsɛm abɛkae sɛ mmara no bɛyɛ nsakrae na ama abortion ho nsunsuansoɔ no akɔ so.</s>

en: Ms. Changamire says many studies show that young girls are losing their lives through abortions.
twi: Ms ɔhangamire kyerɛ nhwehwɛmu da no adi sɛ, mmaa dodoɔ no ara na ɛnam abɔɔhyin nti, wɔhwere wɔn nkwa.
mt0: <pad> Ms. Changamire kae sɛ nhwehwɛmu pii kyerɛ sɛ mmofra a wɔn ho yɛ duru no kɔ so firi abortions mu.</s>

en: Although many young people are pushing for the law to be amended, some older women are opposed to it, saying abortion law should not make abortion more acceptable, saying it will make young people less respectful of life.
twi: ɛmfa ho sɛ mmabunu dodoɔ no ara pɛ sɛ wɔyɛ nsesaeɛ wɔ abɔɔhyin mmara mu no, mmaa mpaninfoɔ no bi nso mpene so. Wɔkyerɛ sɛ ɛnni kwan sɛ abɔɔhyin mmara no ma ho kwan ma wɔgye abɔɔhyinyɛ tom ɛfiri sɛ ɛmma mmabunu no mfa anidie mma nkwa.
mt0: <pad> Ɛwom sɛ mmaa a wɔyɛ mmofra no bɛka sɛ mmara no bɛyɛ nsesaeɛ, mmaa a wɔyɛ afoforɔ no nso ka sɛ mmara no ɛnsɛ sɛ ɛyɛ abortion no adeɛ a ɛyɛ papa, sɛ ɛbɛma mmaa a wɔyɛ mmofra no bɛyɛ nsɛm a ɛyɛ papa.</s>

en: The Termination of Pregnancy Act was enacted by a parliament in 1977 before the country gained full independence.
twi: Mmarahyɛbadwafie hyɛɛ abɔɔhyin mmara no wɔ 1977 mu ansa ɔman no renya ne fahodie.
mt0: <pad> Ɔmanpanin no de ɔkwan a wɔde bɛgye nkwa akɔsɛe yɛɛ ade wɔ 1977 ansa na ɔman no anya tumi akɔsɛe.</s>

mt0: <pad> Zimbabwean police have arrested several members of the MDC-T led by Nelson Chamisa as they tried to enter the party's headquarters at Morgan Tsvangirei House in Harare.</s>
